passage_text:
John Cabot
    
    
        John Cabot was an explorer from Italy who had the same dream as Columbus. He wanted to reach Asia by sailing west across the ocean. But Cabot had a different idea than Columbus. He thought the best way to get to Asia was to sail around the northern part of Earth. The distance around Earth is much shorter at the top than it is at the equator. This would substantially cut down the travel time. Like other explorers, Cabot wanted to find the Northwest Passage. This was supposed to be a shorter route from Europe to Asia.
Many things about Cabot's life are still unknown today. He did not keep good records during his trips. However, we do know he was Italian and got help from King Henry VII of England. The king gave Cabot a charter, which was like a special permission paper. This charter let Cabot explore new lands and claim them for England.

---

Cabot made his first attempt to find the Northwest Passage in 1496. This trip was not successful. He had fights with some of his crew members. There was also a shortage of food, and they ran into terrible weather. Cabot decided to turn around and go back to England.
In 1497, Cabot tried again with one ship and 18 men. This time, he reached land that he thought was Asia. But this land was actually the coast of North America. Nobody knows exactly where he first saw land. It might have been near Newfoundland. During this trip, Cabot found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish. This area is called the Grand Banks, and it is still a great fishing spot today. Cabot and his men were some of the first Europeans to see the landmass we now call North America.

---

Cabot sailed back to England with exciting news. He was sure he had found a new, shorter route to Asia. This helped him get support for another, much larger expedition. This trip left England in 1498, but the ships never came back. Nobody knows what happened to Cabot and his men. Later, people realized that Cabot had not really found the Northwest Passage. But England used Cabot's trips to make claims to North American territory. When Cabot first saw land, he went ashore and claimed it for England.

---

Life on sailing ships was very hard. Young boys worked as pages for the captain. They carried messages, cleaned the deck, and helped serve food. Older boys had to work the bilge pump. This pump removed water that leaked into the ship. It was a terrible job because the water smelled awful and made sailors sick.
The food on ships was also bad. Most of the time, sailors ate hardtack. This was bread that was baked many times until it became very hard. Sailors had to soak it in water to make it soft enough to eat. The good thing about hardtack was that it would not spoil on long trips. But if it got wet, bugs called weevils could get into it. Many sailors got sick from eating such poor food. Lots of them got a disease called scurvy. Today we know that scurvy happens when people don't eat enough fresh fruits and vegetables. Back then, people didn't know this, so many sailors died from this disease.
question: What was one important result of Cabots trips, even though he did not find Asia?
option_1: England used his trips to claim land in North America.
option_2: He found a short route to Asia that many sailors used.
option_3: He kept perfect records, so people know every detail of his life.
option_4: He brought plenty of fresh food, so no sailors got sick.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the main result of Cabot's trips. The story says he "claimed it for England," which helped England get land in North America.
option_2_explanation: Good try! Cabot wanted to find a short route, but he never actually found one. The story shows England got to claim new land because of his trips.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says "He did not keep good records" about his trips. The real result was that England claimed land in North America.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says there was a "shortage of food" on his trip. What really happened was England used his trips to claim new land.

Back then, people didn't know this, so many sailors died from this disease.
question: According to the passage, what made Cabot believe his idea was better than Columbus's approach?
option_1: Sailing north would be safer because there were fewer storms.
option_2: The northern route had more islands where ships could stop for supplies.
option_3: The distance around Earth is shorter at the top, reducing travel time.
option_4: Northern waters had more fish to catch during the journey.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say the north was safer from storms. Actually, Cabot hit terrible weather on his trip!
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story never talks about islands for stopping. Cabot thought his route was better for a different reason.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says "distance around Earth is much shorter at the top." This would make the trip faster than Columbus's way.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Cabot found fish during his trip, but that's not why he thought going north was better. He had a different reason before he left.

single_correct_check: only C is defensible as the text explicitly states this was Cabot's reasoning
diversity_check: targets paragraph 1 about Cabot's theoretical planning - completely different from reference about actual results and different from variant 1 about author perspective

passage_text:
John Cabot
    
    
        John Cabot was an explorer from Italy who had the same dream as Columbus. He wanted to reach Asia by sailing west across the ocean. But Cabot had a different idea than Columbus. He thought the best way to get to Asia was to sail around the northern part of Earth. The distance around Earth is much shorter at the top than it is at the equator. This would substantially cut down the travel time. Like other explorers, Cabot wanted to find the Northwest Passage. This was supposed to be a shorter route from Europe to Asia.
Many things about Cabot's life are still unknown today. He did not keep good records during his trips. However, we do know he was Italian and got help from King Henry VII of England. The king gave Cabot a charter, which was like a special permission paper. This charter let Cabot explore new lands and claim them for England.

---

Cabot made his first attempt to find the Northwest Passage in 1496. This trip was not successful. He had fights with some of his crew members. There was also a shortage of food, and they ran into terrible weather. Cabot decided to turn around and go back to England.
In 1497, Cabot tried again with one ship and 18 men. This time, he reached land that he thought was Asia. But this land was actually the coast of North America. Nobody knows exactly where he first saw land. It might have been near Newfoundland. During this trip, Cabot found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish. This area is called the Grand Banks, and it is still a great fishing spot today. Cabot and his men were some of the first Europeans to see the landmass we now call North America.

---

Cabot sailed back to England with exciting news. He was sure he had found a new, shorter route to Asia. This helped him get support for another, much larger expedition. This trip left England in 1498, but the ships never came back. Nobody knows what happened to Cabot and his men. Later, people realized that Cabot had not really found the Northwest Passage. But England used Cabot's trips to make claims to North American territory. When Cabot first saw land, he went ashore and claimed it for England.

---

Life on sailing ships was very hard. Young boys worked as pages for the captain. They carried messages, cleaned the deck, and helped serve food. Older boys had to work the bilge pump. This pump removed water that leaked into the ship. It was a terrible job because the water smelled awful and made sailors sick.
The food on ships was also bad. Most of the time, sailors ate hardtack. This was bread that was baked many times until it became very hard. Sailors had to soak it in water to make it soft enough to eat. The good thing about hardtack was that it would not spoil on long trips. But if it got wet, bugs called weevils could get into it. Many sailors got sick from eating such poor food. Lots of them got a disease called scurvy. Today we know that scurvy happens when people don't eat enough fresh fruits and vegetables. Back then, people didn't know this, so many sailors died from this disease.
question: Based on the information in the passage, why did King Henry VII give Cabot a charter?
option_1: The charter would help Cabot keep better records during his voyages.
option_2: The charter gave Cabot permission to explore and claim new lands for England.
option_3: The charter provided money to buy food and supplies for the crew.
option_4: The charter protected Cabot from fights with his crew members.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says Cabot didn't keep good records, but the charter wasn't for helping him write things down. The charter was about letting him explore new places.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says "This charter let Cabot explore new lands and claim them for England." The king gave him permission to find new places for England.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the charter wasn't about giving Cabot money for food. The story says the charter was special permission to explore, not help buying supplies.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Cabot still had fights with his crew even with the charter. The charter was about permission to explore new lands, not stopping crew problems.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1's explanation of the charter's purpose and King Henry's support - differs from reference which asks about voyage outcomes
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential purposes or functions of the charter
specificity_check: all choices describe what the charter would do or enable
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 13 words, C: 11 words, D: 10 words - balanced within 30%
semantic_distance_check: distinct functions: record-keeping vs. exploration rights vs. funding vs. crew protection
single_correct_check: only B is defensible based on explicit text definition of charter purpose
diversity_check: targets paragraph 1 about royal support and charter purpose - different from reference about voyage results, variant 1 about author's view, and variant 2 about Cabot's reasoning

passage_text:
John Cabot
    
    
        John Cabot was an explorer from Italy who had the same dream as Columbus. He wanted to reach Asia by sailing west across the ocean. But Cabot had a different idea than Columbus. He thought the best way to get to Asia was to sail around the northern part of Earth. The distance around Earth is much shorter at the top than it is at the equator. This would substantially cut down the travel time. Like other explorers, Cabot wanted to find the Northwest Passage. This was supposed to be a shorter route from Europe to Asia.
Many things about Cabot's life are still unknown today. He did not keep good records during his trips. However, we do know he was Italian and got help from King Henry VII of England. The king gave Cabot a charter, which was like a special permission paper. This charter let Cabot explore new lands and claim them for England.

---

Cabot made his first attempt to find the Northwest Passage in 1496. This trip was not successful. He had fights with some of his crew members. There was also a shortage of food, and they ran into terrible weather. Cabot decided to turn around and go back to England.
In 1497, Cabot tried again with one ship and 18 men. This time, he reached land that he thought was Asia. But this land was actually the coast of North America. Nobody knows exactly where he first saw land. It might have been near Newfoundland. During this trip, Cabot found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish. This area is called the Grand Banks, and it is still a great fishing spot today. Cabot and his men were some of the first Europeans to see the landmass we now call North America.

---

Cabot sailed back to England with exciting news. He was sure he had found a new, shorter route to Asia. This helped him get support for another, much larger expedition. This trip left England in 1498, but the ships never came back. Nobody knows what happened to Cabot and his men. Later, people realized that Cabot had not really found the Northwest Passage. But England used Cabot's trips to make claims to North American territory. When Cabot first saw land, he went ashore and claimed it for England.

---

Life on sailing ships was very hard. Young boys worked as pages for the captain. They carried messages, cleaned the deck, and helped serve food. Older boys had to work the bilge pump. This pump removed water that leaked into the ship. It was a terrible job because the water smelled awful and made sailors sick.
The food on ships was also bad. Most of the time, sailors ate hardtack. This was bread that was baked many times until it became very hard. Sailors had to soak it in water to make it soft enough to eat. The good thing about hardtack was that it would not spoil on long trips. But if it got wet, bugs called weevils could get into it. Many sailors got sick from eating such poor food. Lots of them got a disease called scurvy. Today we know that scurvy happens when people don't eat enough fresh fruits and vegetables. Back then, people didn't know this, so many sailors died from this disease.
question: Why was John Cabot's 1497 voyage still important to England, even though he did not reach Asia?
option_1: He brought back ships full of gold and spices
option_2: He found rich fishing waters near Newfoundland
option_3: He proved the Northwest Passage was real
option_4: He discovered a short sea route to Asia
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say Cabot brought back gold or spices. It says he "found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish."
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the right detail from the story. The passage says Cabot "found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish" near Newfoundland.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says Cabot didn't really find the Northwest Passage. Instead, he "found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish."
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Cabot thought he found a short route to Asia, but he didn't. The story says he "found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish."

passage_text:
John Cabot
    
    
        John Cabot was an explorer from Italy who had the same dream as Columbus. He wanted to reach Asia by sailing west across the ocean. But Cabot had a different idea than Columbus. He thought the best way to get to Asia was to sail around the northern part of Earth. The distance around Earth is much shorter at the top than it is at the equator. This would substantially cut down the travel time. Like other explorers, Cabot wanted to find the Northwest Passage. This was supposed to be a shorter route from Europe to Asia.
Many things about Cabot's life are still unknown today. He did not keep good records during his trips. However, we do know he was Italian and got help from King Henry VII of England. The king gave Cabot a charter, which was like a special permission paper. This charter let Cabot explore new lands and claim them for England.

---

Cabot made his first attempt to find the Northwest Passage in 1496. This trip was not successful. He had fights with some of his crew members. There was also a shortage of food, and they ran into terrible weather. Cabot decided to turn around and go back to England.
In 1497, Cabot tried again with one ship and 18 men. This time, he reached land that he thought was Asia. But this land was actually the coast of North America. Nobody knows exactly where he first saw land. It might have been near Newfoundland. During this trip, Cabot found an area of shallow water that had lots of fish. This area is called the Grand Banks, and it is still a great fishing spot today. Cabot and his men were some of the first Europeans to see the landmass we now call North America.

---

Cabot sailed back to England with exciting news. He was sure he had found a new, shorter route to Asia. This helped him get support for another, much larger expedition. This trip left England in 1498, but the ships never came back. Nobody knows what happened to Cabot and his men. Later, people realized that Cabot had not really found the Northwest Passage. But England used Cabot's trips to make claims to North American territory. When Cabot first saw land, he went ashore and claimed it for England.

---

Life on sailing ships was very hard. Young boys worked as pages for the captain. They carried messages, cleaned the deck, and helped serve food. Older boys had to work the bilge pump. This pump removed water that leaked into the ship. It was a terrible job because the water smelled awful and made sailors sick.
The food on ships was also bad. Most of the time, sailors ate hardtack. This was bread that was baked many times until it became very hard. Sailors had to soak it in water to make it soft enough to eat. The good thing about hardtack was that it would not spoil on long trips. But if it got wet, bugs called weevils could get into it. Many sailors got sick from eating such poor food. Lots of them got a disease called scurvy. Today we know that scurvy happens when people don't eat enough fresh fruits and vegetables. Back then, people didn't know this, so many sailors died from this disease.
question: What is the main idea of the entire passage about John Cabot?
option_1: John Cabot's explorations opened North American territory for England, even though he never found the route to Asia he sought.
option_2: Life on sailing ships in the 1400s was extremely difficult because of poor food, hard work, and dangerous diseases.
option_3: The Northwest Passage was the goal of many explorers, but John Cabot was unable to prove it existed during his voyages.
option_4: John Cabot kept such poor records that historians today cannot determine exactly where he landed in North America.
option_1_explanation: You got it! The story tells how Cabot "wanted to reach Asia" but found North America and "claim them for England" instead.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story mentions hard times on ships, but it's mostly about Cabot's trips and what he found for England.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story is about all of Cabot's trips, not just the Northwest Passage. It focuses on how he helped England get new land.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Poor records are mentioned, but the main story is about Cabot's voyages and how they helped England get territory.
differentiation_notes: Asks about entire passage's main idea synthesizing Cabot's goals, actions, and outcomes - differs from reference which asks about passage PURPOSE ('most likely written to')
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential main ideas or central messages of the passage
specificity_check: all choices are complete statements summarizing major content
length_check: A: 19 words, B: 19 words, C: 20 words, D: 17 words - balanced within 18%
semantic_distance_check: distinct focuses: exploration outcomes vs. sailor hardships vs. passage search vs. historical gaps
single_correct_check: only A is defensible as it encompasses his voyages, discoveries, and England's benefit
diversity_check: targets overall passage synthesis about Cabot's exploration impact - different question asking 'what is main idea' vs. reference's 'most likely written to'

passage_text:
Henry Hudson
    
    
        An Englishman named Henry Hudson tried four times to find the Northwest Passage. He died trying. First, in 1607, he tried sailing north from England. If you look at a globe, you can see what he was trying to do. He knew that Earth was round and he thought he could sail across the North Pole. He didn't know that solid ice always covers the Arctic Ocean.
"I hoped to have a clear sea," Hudson wrote about his first trip, "but that was not possible because of the ice around us." Hudson tried again in 1608. He sailed northeast and again found icebergs and freezing cold weather. He turned his boat around and tried sailing northwest. When his crew saw that they weren't going home, they decided to rebel against Hudson. They said they wouldn't work unless they sailed back to England. So, home they went.

---

In 1609, Henry Hudson sailed west. This time, he was working for a group of businessmen called the Dutch East India Company. On this trip, he reached North America and claimed land for Holland. Hudson saw many native people. One man who sailed with him wrote in his journal, "They are dressed well in loose deer skins and brought green tobacco which they gave us in exchange for knives and beads." The native people also gave the sailors bread made of maize.
Hudson sailed past "a very good piece of ground and a cliff close by of white-green color...on the side of the river called Manna-hata." It was the island we now call Manhattan, which is the center of New York City today. Next, Hudson sailed up a river that still has his name. You can find the Hudson River on a map of New York state.

---

After a long day of work, sailors were ready to fall into bed and rest their tired bodies. They were ready, but there were no beds for them. The captain had a bed to sleep in, but the sailors did not. They slept on the deck. As the ship moved back and forth with the waves, the sailors moved with it. Most sailors had to stand watch for part of the night. When that was done, they could sleep for a few hours. In the morning, they would get up and do it all over again.

---

In 1610, Hudson tried once more to find a shortcut from Europe to Asia. He sailed a ship called Discovery into a wide area of water in the northern part of Canada. Today, it is named after him: the Hudson Bay. On the map, Hudson Bay looks like a big, open body of water. But in many places, the water gets too shallow for sailing. In many other places, it is frozen almost all year long.
Once again, Henry Hudson had sailed into icy waters just as winter was coming. Hudson and his crew went on land during the winter. They ran out of food and water. Some of the crew got sick. Some died. The sailors blamed Hudson for caring more about finding the Northwest Passage than about keeping his crew safe and healthy. When the ice began to melt, the crew rebelled again. They forced Hudson, his son, and a few crew members who were loyal to Hudson to get into a small boat with no oars. Then, they left them behind and sailed the Discovery back to England. No one ever heard from Henry Hudson again.
question: According to the passage, what did the sailors think about Hudson near the end?
option_1: He was just unlucky with the ice and the weather.
option_2: He cared more about his goal than their safety.
option_3: He always kept them safe and healthy, no matter what.
option_4: He decided to give up after his first trip and stop exploring.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The sailors weren't just upset about bad weather. They were mad because Hudson put finding the passage before keeping them safe.
option_2_explanation: Great job! When his crew saw "they weren't going home," they rebelled against Hudson. You found the right reason why the sailors turned against him.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's not what happened! The sailors actually rebelled against Hudson because he wouldn't take them home when they wanted to go.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Hudson didn't give up after his first trip - he "tried four times." The sailors were upset because he cared more about exploring than their safety.

option_2_explanation: Great job! Hudson wrote "I hoped to have a clear sea" but ice blocked his path. You found his exact words!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Hudson's journal talked about ice blocking him, not about the North Pole being too far away.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Hudson didn't quit after writing this. The story says he tried four times total!

passage_text:
Henry Hudson
    
    
        An Englishman named Henry Hudson tried four times to find the Northwest Passage. He died trying. First, in 1607, he tried sailing north from England. If you look at a globe, you can see what he was trying to do. He knew that Earth was round and he thought he could sail across the North Pole. He didn't know that solid ice always covers the Arctic Ocean.
"I hoped to have a clear sea," Hudson wrote about his first trip, "but that was not possible because of the ice around us." Hudson tried again in 1608. He sailed northeast and again found icebergs and freezing cold weather. He turned his boat around and tried sailing northwest. When his crew saw that they weren't going home, they decided to rebel against Hudson. They said they wouldn't work unless they sailed back to England. So, home they went.

---

In 1609, Henry Hudson sailed west. This time, he was working for a group of businessmen called the Dutch East India Company. On this trip, he reached North America and claimed land for Holland. Hudson saw many native people. One man who sailed with him wrote in his journal, "They are dressed well in loose deer skins and brought green tobacco which they gave us in exchange for knives and beads." The native people also gave the sailors bread made of maize.
Hudson sailed past "a very good piece of ground and a cliff close by of white-green color...on the side of the river called Manna-hata." It was the island we now call Manhattan, which is the center of New York City today. Next, Hudson sailed up a river that still has his name. You can find the Hudson River on a map of New York state.

---

After a long day of work, sailors were ready to fall into bed and rest their tired bodies. They were ready, but there were no beds for them. The captain had a bed to sleep in, but the sailors did not. They slept on the deck. As the ship moved back and forth with the waves, the sailors moved with it. Most sailors had to stand watch for part of the night. When that was done, they could sleep for a few hours. In the morning, they would get up and do it all over again.

---

In 1610, Hudson tried once more to find a shortcut from Europe to Asia. He sailed a ship called Discovery into a wide area of water in the northern part of Canada. Today, it is named after him: the Hudson Bay. On the map, Hudson Bay looks like a big, open body of water. But in many places, the water gets too shallow for sailing. In many other places, it is frozen almost all year long.
Once again, Henry Hudson had sailed into icy waters just as winter was coming. Hudson and his crew went on land during the winter. They ran out of food and water. Some of the crew got sick. Some died. The sailors blamed Hudson for caring more about finding the Northwest Passage than about keeping his crew safe and healthy. When the ice began to melt, the crew rebelled again. They forced Hudson, his son, and a few crew members who were loyal to Hudson to get into a small boat with no oars. Then, they left them behind and sailed the Discovery back to England. No one ever heard from Henry Hudson again.
question: Which detail from the passage shows Hudson's own view of what was possible on his first voyage?
option_1: He wrote that he knew Earth was round and could sail across the North Pole.
option_2: He discovered that solid ice always covers the Arctic Ocean in all seasons.
option_3: He learned from other explorers that the ice would block his path northward.
option_4: He thought his crew would rebel if they encountered freezing cold weather.
option_1_explanation: You got it! The story says "he thought he could sail across the North Pole." This shows what Hudson believed was possible.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story tells us what Hudson didn't know, not what he thought. We need to find Hudson's own ideas.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story never says Hudson learned from other explorers. We need to find what Hudson himself believed.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the crew problem happened on his second trip, not his first. Plus, Hudson didn't expect it to happen.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 1, Hudson's initial belief about sailing across North Pole - differs from reference asking about sailors' final view of Hudson. Requires identifying Hudson's documented thoughts before his voyage.
homogeneity_check: all choices are statements about Hudson's knowledge or beliefs before/during his first voyage
specificity_check: all choices describe what Hudson supposedly knew, thought, or learned
length_check: A: 16 words, B: 13 words, C: 13 words, D: 13 words - balanced within 23%
semantic_distance_check: each presents different type of knowledge: his belief vs. discovery vs. learning from others vs. crew prediction
single_correct_check: only A directly states Hudson's documented perspective from the text
diversity_check: targets paragraph 1 about Hudson's pre-voyage belief system - different from all other variants and reference

question: Based on Hudson's experiences on his four voyages, what can you conclude was the main challenge of Arctic exploration in the early 1600s?
option_1: Crew members often became frightened and refused to continue sailing.
option_2: Ice and freezing weather made the routes extremely dangerous.
option_3: Food and water supplies ran out too quickly on long trips.
option_4: Ships were not built strong enough for long ocean voyages.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The crew did refuse to work, but that happened because of the dangerous ice and cold. The story shows the real problem was 'ice around us' making travel unsafe.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found the key details about 'ice around us' and freezing weather. The story keeps talking about ice and cold as the biggest danger.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say they ran out of food and water. It keeps mentioning 'ice around us' and freezing weather as the main problem.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story never says the ships were too weak. It talks about 'ice around us' and freezing weather making the trips dangerous.

question: Why did Hudson keep trying to find the Northwest Passage even after failing three times?
option_1: The Dutch East India Company forced him to continue exploring against his will.
option_2: He wanted to prove to his crew that he was smarter than they were.
option_3: Ice only blocked some routes, so he believed other paths might work better.
option_4: Each country he worked for promised to make him rich if he succeeded.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say the Dutch East India Company forced Hudson to keep exploring. Hudson chose to try four different times because he really wanted to find the passage.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story never talks about Hudson wanting to prove he was smart to his crew. He kept trying because he thought different paths might work better.
option_3_explanation: You got it! Hudson tried four different ways because "ice around us" blocked each route. He thought other paths might not have ice problems.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story mentions the Dutch East India Company but never says anyone promised to make Hudson rich. He kept trying for different reasons.

option_1: after the ice began to melt
option_2: as soon as they reached Hudson Bay
option_3: while they were spending winter on land
option_4: before they ran out of food and water
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the right time clue in the story. The text says "when the ice began to melt" the crew left Hudson.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says they left Hudson "when the ice began to melt," not right when they got to Hudson Bay. That happened after winter ended.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but they stayed with Hudson all winter long. The story says "when the ice began to melt" they left him, which was after winter.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! They did run out of food in winter, but stayed with Hudson then. The story says they left "when the ice began to melt."

passage_text:
Henry Hudson
    
    
        An Englishman named Henry Hudson tried four times to find the Northwest Passage. He died trying. First, in 1607, he tried sailing north from England. If you look at a globe, you can see what he was trying to do. He knew that Earth was round and he thought he could sail across the North Pole. He didn't know that solid ice always covers the Arctic Ocean.
"I hoped to have a clear sea," Hudson wrote about his first trip, "but that was not possible because of the ice around us." Hudson tried again in 1608. He sailed northeast and again found icebergs and freezing cold weather. He turned his boat around and tried sailing northwest. When his crew saw that they weren't going home, they decided to rebel against Hudson. They said they wouldn't work unless they sailed back to England. So, home they went.

---

In 1609, Henry Hudson sailed west. This time, he was working for a group of businessmen called the Dutch East India Company. On this trip, he reached North America and claimed land for Holland. Hudson saw many native people. One man who sailed with him wrote in his journal, "They are dressed well in loose deer skins and brought green tobacco which they gave us in exchange for knives and beads." The native people also gave the sailors bread made of maize.
Hudson sailed past "a very good piece of ground and a cliff close by of white-green color...on the side of the river called Manna-hata." It was the island we now call Manhattan, which is the center of New York City today. Next, Hudson sailed up a river that still has his name. You can find the Hudson River on a map of New York state.

---

After a long day of work, sailors were ready to fall into bed and rest their tired bodies. They were ready, but there were no beds for them. The captain had a bed to sleep in, but the sailors did not. They slept on the deck. As the ship moved back and forth with the waves, the sailors moved with it. Most sailors had to stand watch for part of the night. When that was done, they could sleep for a few hours. In the morning, they would get up and do it all over again.

---

In 1610, Hudson tried once more to find a shortcut from Europe to Asia. He sailed a ship called Discovery into a wide area of water in the northern part of Canada. Today, it is named after him: the Hudson Bay. On the map, Hudson Bay looks like a big, open body of water. But in many places, the water gets too shallow for sailing. In many other places, it is frozen almost all year long.
Once again, Henry Hudson had sailed into icy waters just as winter was coming. Hudson and his crew went on land during the winter. They ran out of food and water. Some of the crew got sick. Some died. The sailors blamed Hudson for caring more about finding the Northwest Passage than about keeping his crew safe and healthy. When the ice began to melt, the crew rebelled again. They forced Hudson, his son, and a few crew members who were loyal to Hudson to get into a small boat with no oars. Then, they left them behind and sailed the Discovery back to England. No one ever heard from Henry Hudson again.
question: According to the passage, what happened between the time Hudson reached North America in 1609 and when he tried sailing into Hudson Bay in 1610?
option_1: He spent a year training a new crew who would be more loyal to him.
option_2: He worked for different employers on separate exploration attempts to find routes.
option_3: He wrote a book about his discoveries to help other explorers avoid mistakes.
option_4: He returned to England to repair his ship and gather more food supplies.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say Hudson trained crews or spent a year getting ready. It just tells us he made another trip in 1610.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says Hudson "worked for the Dutch East India Company" in 1609, then made another separate trip. These were different trips for different people.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story mentions Hudson writing in his journal, not a whole book. Writing notes is different from writing a book to help others.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't tell us Hudson went back to fix his ship or get more food. It just moves from his 1609 trip to his 1610 trip.
differentiation_notes: Targets the transition between paragraphs 3 and 5, analyzing what occurred between 1609 and 1610 voyages - differs from reference about timing of abandonment. Requires understanding voyage sequence and employment changes.
homogeneity_check: all choices are events that allegedly happened between the 1609 and 1610 voyages
specificity_check: all choices describe activities during the time gap between voyages

semantic_distance_check: each presents different intervening activity: crew training vs. separate expeditions vs. book writing vs. ship repair
single_correct_check: only B is supported by the text showing distinct voyages for different purposes
diversity_check: targets the sequence between paragraphs 3-5 about voyage transitions - different from reference and other variants

passage_text:
Henry Hudson
    
    
        An Englishman named Henry Hudson tried four times to find the Northwest Passage. He died trying. First, in 1607, he tried sailing north from England. If you look at a globe, you can see what he was trying to do. He knew that Earth was round and he thought he could sail across the North Pole. He didn't know that solid ice always covers the Arctic Ocean.
"I hoped to have a clear sea," Hudson wrote about his first trip, "but that was not possible because of the ice around us." Hudson tried again in 1608. He sailed northeast and again found icebergs and freezing cold weather. He turned his boat around and tried sailing northwest. When his crew saw that they weren't going home, they decided to rebel against Hudson. They said they wouldn't work unless they sailed back to England. So, home they went.

---

In 1609, Henry Hudson sailed west. This time, he was working for a group of businessmen called the Dutch East India Company. On this trip, he reached North America and claimed land for Holland. Hudson saw many native people. One man who sailed with him wrote in his journal, "They are dressed well in loose deer skins and brought green tobacco which they gave us in exchange for knives and beads." The native people also gave the sailors bread made of maize.
Hudson sailed past "a very good piece of ground and a cliff close by of white-green color...on the side of the river called Manna-hata." It was the island we now call Manhattan, which is the center of New York City today. Next, Hudson sailed up a river that still has his name. You can find the Hudson River on a map of New York state.

---

After a long day of work, sailors were ready to fall into bed and rest their tired bodies. They were ready, but there were no beds for them. The captain had a bed to sleep in, but the sailors did not. They slept on the deck. As the ship moved back and forth with the waves, the sailors moved with it. Most sailors had to stand watch for part of the night. When that was done, they could sleep for a few hours. In the morning, they would get up and do it all over again.

---

In 1610, Hudson tried once more to find a shortcut from Europe to Asia. He sailed a ship called Discovery into a wide area of water in the northern part of Canada. Today, it is named after him: the Hudson Bay. On the map, Hudson Bay looks like a big, open body of water. But in many places, the water gets too shallow for sailing. In many other places, it is frozen almost all year long.
Once again, Henry Hudson had sailed into icy waters just as winter was coming. Hudson and his crew went on land during the winter. They ran out of food and water. Some of the crew got sick. Some died. The sailors blamed Hudson for caring more about finding the Northwest Passage than about keeping his crew safe and healthy. When the ice began to melt, the crew rebelled again. They forced Hudson, his son, and a few crew members who were loyal to Hudson to get into a small boat with no oars. Then, they left them behind and sailed the Discovery back to England. No one ever heard from Henry Hudson again.
question: How do the details about Hudson trying different routes support the main idea that he was a determined explorer?
option_1: Each failed route made Hudson angry, which proved he cared deeply about succeeding.
option_2: Hudson sailed in all four directions trying to find any possible path to Asia.
option_3: The details show Hudson gave up after two tries because he realized it was impossible.
option_4: Hudson always used the same route but tried sailing during different seasons.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say Hudson got angry about failing. It shows he was determined by trying "four times" in different directions.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! Hudson tried going "north," then northeast, then west, and finally to Hudson Bay. He kept trying different ways to find a path!
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Hudson tried four times, not two, and "died trying." He never gave up - he kept going until the end.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Hudson used different routes each time. He went "north," then "northeast," then "west" - not the same way.
differentiation_notes: Targets details across paragraphs 1-2 and 5 about varied routes supporting determination theme - differs from reference about sailor night conditions. Requires connecting geographical variety to character trait.
homogeneity_check: all choices are explanations of how route details support the determination main idea
specificity_check: all choices connect Hudson's actions/routes to the concept of determination
length_check: A: 13 words, B: 14 words, C: 14 words, D: 11 words - balanced within 27%
semantic_distance_check: each presents different connection: anger motivation vs. directional variety vs. giving up vs. seasonal timing
single_correct_check: only B accurately describes the directional variety documented in the passage
diversity_check: targets multiple paragraphs connecting route diversity to determination - different synthesis task from reference

They forced Hudson, his son, and a few crew members who were loyal to Hudson to get into a small boat with no oars. Then, they left them behind and sailed the Discovery back to England. No one ever heard from Henry Hudson again.
question: Based on the passage, how does the description of Hudson Bay's characteristics in paragraph 5 connect to what happened to Hudson and his crew there?
option_1: The bay's beauty and wildlife provided food that kept the crew healthy all winter long.
option_2: The bay's shallow and frozen conditions trapped them, leading to starvation and rebellion.
option_3: The bay's large size gave them plenty of room to sail safely during the winter months.
option_4: The bay's warm waters allowed them to fish successfully and survive comfortably.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says the crew got sick and "ran out of food," not that they stayed healthy. The bay was harsh and cold, not helpful.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The bay was "frozen" and "too shallow for sailing," which trapped them. This made them starve and turn against Hudson.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The bay looked big but was "too shallow" and "frozen," so they couldn't sail safely. Size wasn't the problem.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the bay had frozen water, not warm water. The crew "ran out of food" instead of fishing successfully.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 5, linking Hudson Bay's geographic description to crisis outcome - differs from reference about how trip details support main idea. Requires connecting place characteristics to human consequences through cause-effect reasoning.
homogeneity_check: all choices explain connections between Hudson Bay features and crew outcomes
specificity_check: all choices link specific bay characteristics to specific human results
length_check: A: 14 words, B: 12 words, C: 15 words, D: 12 words - balanced within 25%
semantic_distance_check: each presents different connection: beauty/food vs. shallow/frozen trap vs. size/safety vs. warmth/fishing
single_correct_check: only B accurately connects the documented harsh features to documented tragic outcomes
diversity_check: targets paragraph 5 with geographic-to-human consequence analysis - different causal reasoning focus from all other variants

article_title: The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
passage_text:
The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
    
    
        Many French people came to North America in the 1600s and 1700s to trade for animal furs. These traders worked with Native American people. They would barter by giving European goods to get animal skins and furs in return.
The traders collected many kinds of fur, but they wanted beaver pelts the most. Beaver hats were very popular in Europe. People would buy beaver hats in England, France, Germany, and Russia. Beaver fur is thick and waterproof, so it kept heads warm and dry. Some hat makers used beaver fur to make soft, puffy hats. Others made the fur into felt, which was smooth and waterproof.
In many parts of Europe, hunters had killed too many beavers. The beavers had almost gone extinct. Europeans could not get beaver pelts at home, so they were willing to pay for pelts from North America.

---

Samuel de Champlain and other French explorers led the fur trade. They built trading posts in North America along the Atlantic Coast, in Quebec, along the St. Lawrence River, and near the Great Lakes.
In July 1609, Champlain traveled down a river to a large lake that would later be named Lake Champlain. He wrote about his journey. The lake had many pretty islands with fine forests and lush meadows. There were countless birds and wild animals like deer, bears, and fawns. Many rivers emptied into the lake, and it had great numbers of fish. Champlain saw chestnut trees he had never seen before. Mountains in the distance had snow on top, and he learned that the Iroquois people lived in the beautiful valleys there.

---

The French made treaties with different Native American groups, including the Algonquin and Huron people. These agreements meant they would trade peacefully together. Native people would bring beaver pelts they had gathered themselves or had gotten by trading with other tribes.
Native people wanted to obtain things made of metal because most tribes did not make their own metal products. They would trade furs for knives, ax blades, kettles, and fish hooks. They also wanted glass beads from Europe, wool blankets, tobacco, guns, and gunpowder.
The French would collect lots of beaver pelts and ship them back to France to sell. They made a lot of money this way. The fur trade covered a huge expanse of North America and continued for two hundred years. It was so important to Canada's history that in 2011, Canada put a beaver on the back of their nickel coin.
question: According to Section 3, which action happens immediately before the French sell the beaver pelts in Europe?
option_1: Ship the pelts across the Atlantic to French ports.
option_2: Trade with Native peoples for furs in North America.
option_3: Negotiate treaties with Native groups to maintain peaceful trade.
option_4: Trap and collect beaver pelts in North America.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the right step that happens right before selling. The story shows the French "ship them back to France to sell."
option_2_explanation: Good try! Trading happens earlier in the process. The story says after getting pelts, the French "ship them back to France to sell."
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but treaties aren't mentioned in this part. The story says the French "ship them back to France to sell" the pelts.
option_4_explanation: Close! But Native people did the trapping, not the French. The French "ship them back to France to sell" after getting the pelts.

article_title: The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
passage_text:
The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
    
    
        Many French people came to North America in the 1600s and 1700s to trade for animal furs. These traders worked with Native American people. They would barter by giving European goods to get animal skins and furs in return.
The traders collected many kinds of fur, but they wanted beaver pelts the most. Beaver hats were very popular in Europe. People would buy beaver hats in England, France, Germany, and Russia. Beaver fur is thick and waterproof, so it kept heads warm and dry. Some hat makers used beaver fur to make soft, puffy hats. Others made the fur into felt, which was smooth and waterproof.
In many parts of Europe, hunters had killed too many beavers. The beavers had almost gone extinct. Europeans could not get beaver pelts at home, so they were willing to pay for pelts from North America.

---

Samuel de Champlain and other French explorers led the fur trade. They built trading posts in North America along the Atlantic Coast, in Quebec, along the St. Lawrence River, and near the Great Lakes.
In July 1609, Champlain traveled down a river to a large lake that would later be named Lake Champlain. He wrote about his journey. The lake had many pretty islands with fine forests and lush meadows. There were countless birds and wild animals like deer, bears, and fawns. Many rivers emptied into the lake, and it had great numbers of fish. Champlain saw chestnut trees he had never seen before. Mountains in the distance had snow on top, and he learned that the Iroquois people lived in the beautiful valleys there.

---

The French made treaties with different Native American groups, including the Algonquin and Huron people. These agreements meant they would trade peacefully together. Native people would bring beaver pelts they had gathered themselves or had gotten by trading with other tribes.
Native people wanted to obtain things made of metal because most tribes did not make their own metal products. They would trade furs for knives, ax blades, kettles, and fish hooks. They also wanted glass beads from Europe, wool blankets, tobacco, guns, and gunpowder.
The French would collect lots of beaver pelts and ship them back to France to sell. They made a lot of money this way. The fur trade covered a huge expanse of North America and continued for two hundred years. It was so important to Canada's history that in 2011, Canada put a beaver on the back of their nickel coin.
question: What information from Section 2 shows that the lake region had abundant natural resources?
option_1: Champlain traveled down a river in July 1609.
option_2: The lake would later be named after Champlain himself.
option_3: The lake had countless birds, wild animals, and great numbers of fish.
option_4: Mountains in the distance had snow on their peaks.
option_1_explanation: Good try! This tells us when Champlain traveled, but it doesn't tell us about animals, fish, or other resources. The story shows us what he found at the lake.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but naming the lake after Champlain doesn't show us resources. The story tells us about the animals and fish he saw there.
option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says there were "countless birds" and "great numbers of fish." These words show there were lots of animals and fish.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Mountains with snow tell us about the land, but not about resources like animals or fish. Look for words that show lots of living things.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 2 evidence of natural abundance - differs from reference which asks about trading post locations, and Variant 2 which asks about beaver endangerment
homogeneity_check: all choices are details from Champlain's description in Section 2
specificity_check: all provide specific descriptive details from the passage
length_check: A:9 words, B:10 words, C:13 words, D:9 words - balanced within 44%
semantic_distance_check: each detail describes different aspects of the region
single_correct_check: only C is defensible as evidence of abundant resources
diversity_check: analyzes Section 2 resource description - different from reference and previous variants focusing on other sections/topics

article_title: The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
passage_text:
The Fur Trade and Samuel de Champlain
    
    
        Many French people came to North America in the 1600s and 1700s to trade for animal furs. These traders worked with Native American people. They would barter by giving European goods to get animal skins and furs in return.
The traders collected many kinds of fur, but they wanted beaver pelts the most. Beaver hats were very popular in Europe. People would buy beaver hats in England, France, Germany, and Russia. Beaver fur is thick and waterproof, so it kept heads warm and dry. Some hat makers used beaver fur to make soft, puffy hats. Others made the fur into felt, which was smooth and waterproof.
In many parts of Europe, hunters had killed too many beavers. The beavers had almost gone extinct. Europeans could not get beaver pelts at home, so they were willing to pay for pelts from North America.

---

Samuel de Champlain and other French explorers led the fur trade. They built trading posts in North America along the Atlantic Coast, in Quebec, along the St. Lawrence River, and near the Great Lakes.
In July 1609, Champlain traveled down a river to a large lake that would later be named Lake Champlain. He wrote about his journey. The lake had many pretty islands with fine forests and lush meadows. There were countless birds and wild animals like deer, bears, and fawns. Many rivers emptied into the lake, and it had great numbers of fish. Champlain saw chestnut trees he had never seen before. Mountains in the distance had snow on top, and he learned that the Iroquois people lived in the beautiful valleys there.

---

The French made treaties with different Native American groups, including the Algonquin and Huron people. These agreements meant they would trade peacefully together. Native people would bring beaver pelts they had gathered themselves or had gotten by trading with other tribes.
Native people wanted to obtain things made of metal because most tribes did not make their own metal products. They would trade furs for knives, ax blades, kettles, and fish hooks. They also wanted glass beads from Europe, wool blankets, tobacco, guns, and gunpowder.
The French would collect lots of beaver pelts and ship them back to France to sell. They made a lot of money this way. The fur trade covered a huge expanse of North America and continued for two hundred years. It was so important to Canada's history that in 2011, Canada put a beaver on the back of their nickel coin.
question: The passage explains that Canada put a beaver on their nickel in 2011. What main idea does this detail support?
option_1: Beaver fur can be made into different types of hats.
option_2: The fur trade was extremely important to Canada's history.
option_3: Native American people traded many kinds of animal furs.
option_4: Samuel de Champlain explored lakes and rivers in North America.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The beaver on the coin isn't about making hats. The story shows Canada picked the beaver because fur trading was super important to their country.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says "fur trade was so important to Canada's history" that they put a beaver on their coin. This shows how important fur trading was to Canada.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the beaver coin isn't about trading different kinds of furs. The story says Canada picked the beaver because the fur trade was really important to their history.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The beaver coin doesn't honor Champlain's exploring. The story tells us Canada chose the beaver because the fur trade was so important to their country.

article_title: A History of People in North America
passage_text:
A History of People in North America
    
    
        Many people think that Columbus was the first person to arrive in America. But that is not correct. There are at least two other groups of people who came to North America many years before Christopher Columbus ever sailed across the ocean.
One group was the Vikings. The Vikings lived in Northern Europe, in a place called Scandinavia. They sailed around the world in their strong ships. Sometimes they would raid other places, taking things that did not belong to them. In the year 982, some Vikings left Iceland and made their homes in Greenland. Greenland is part of North America. They arrived there about 500 years before Columbus made his famous trip.

---

The Viking settlements in Greenland grew bigger over time. Scientists who study old things think there were probably 3,000 to 5,000 Viking settlers living there at one time. The Vikings had farms and made their income by raising animals and trading with other people. But after many years, the Vikings decided to leave Greenland. They had to abandon their settlements in the 1400s, not long before Columbus made his voyage.
The Vikings also explored other lands west of Greenland. Around the year 1000, a famous Viking explorer named Leif Eriksson visited a land that he and other Vikings called Vinland. Most experts believe Vinland was somewhere along the coast of Newfoundland, which is in modern-day Canada. There is strong evidence that some Vikings made settlements in Newfoundland. In 1960, scientists found the ruins of an old Viking village there. This village may have been part of Vinland.

---

The Vikings definitely reached America before Columbus did. So maybe we should say the Vikings were the first Europeans to settle in North America. But before we decide this, we need to learn about another group that came to North America.
Another group that settled in North America was the Native Americans. Even though we call these people "Native" Americans, they did not always live in the Americas. They came to America from Asia many thousands of years ago. When and how this happened is something that scientists still talk about and study.

---

Some historians think the first settlers made their way to North America a little more than 15,000 years ago. Other scientists think the first people came to America much earlier than that. They think it might have been 40,000 years ago. Some experts believe these people walked across land when Alaska and Asia were connected. Others think they may have traveled along the coast in boats.
Experts think the first humans lived in Africa. About 100,000 years ago, some humans moved out of Africa and into the Middle East. About 70,000 years ago, a group of humans moved into southeast Asia. About 15,000 years ago, some of these people crossed from Asia to the Americas. Scientists believe that many people also came to North America by traveling in ships along different routes. New discoveries are made every day about early settlers in North America, and these discoveries help us learn more about who lived there long ago.
question: What is the main topic of Section 2?
option_1: Columbus's famous voyage.
option_2: Why Vikings raided other places.
option_3: Viking ships and exploration.
option_4: Viking settlements in Greenland.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Columbus is mentioned, but Section 2 is mostly about Vikings living in Greenland. The story says "Viking settlements in Greenland grew bigger" and talks about their farms and leaving.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Section 2 doesn't talk about raiding at all. It's about Vikings who lived in Greenland and says "settlements in Greenland grew bigger" and tells about their farms.

option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea because Section 2 says "Viking settlements in Greenland grew bigger" and tells about their farms and leaving. The whole section is about Vikings living in Greenland!

article_title: A History of People in North America
passage_text:
A History of People in North America
    
    
        Many people think that Columbus was the first person to arrive in America. But that is not correct. There are at least two other groups of people who came to North America many years before Christopher Columbus ever sailed across the ocean.
One group was the Vikings. The Vikings lived in Northern Europe, in a place called Scandinavia. They sailed around the world in their strong ships. Sometimes they would raid other places, taking things that did not belong to them. In the year 982, some Vikings left Iceland and made their homes in Greenland. Greenland is part of North America. They arrived there about 500 years before Columbus made his famous trip.

---

The Viking settlements in Greenland grew bigger over time. Scientists who study old things think there were probably 3,000 to 5,000 Viking settlers living there at one time. The Vikings had farms and made their income by raising animals and trading with other people. But after many years, the Vikings decided to leave Greenland. They had to abandon their settlements in the 1400s, not long before Columbus made his voyage.
The Vikings also explored other lands west of Greenland. Around the year 1000, a famous Viking explorer named Leif Eriksson visited a land that he and other Vikings called Vinland. Most experts believe Vinland was somewhere along the coast of Newfoundland, which is in modern-day Canada. There is strong evidence that some Vikings made settlements in Newfoundland. In 1960, scientists found the ruins of an old Viking village there. This village may have been part of Vinland.

---

The Vikings definitely reached America before Columbus did. So maybe we should say the Vikings were the first Europeans to settle in North America. But before we decide this, we need to learn about another group that came to North America.
Another group that settled in North America was the Native Americans. Even though we call these people "Native" Americans, they did not always live in the Americas. They came to America from Asia many thousands of years ago. When and how this happened is something that scientists still talk about and study.

---

Some historians think the first settlers made their way to North America a little more than 15,000 years ago. Other scientists think the first people came to America much earlier than that. They think it might have been 40,000 years ago. Some experts believe these people walked across land when Alaska and Asia were connected. Others think they may have traveled along the coast in boats.
Experts think the first humans lived in Africa. About 100,000 years ago, some humans moved out of Africa and into the Middle East. About 70,000 years ago, a group of humans moved into southeast Asia. About 15,000 years ago, some of these people crossed from Asia to the Americas. Scientists believe that many people also came to North America by traveling in ships along different routes. New discoveries are made every day about early settlers in North America, and these discoveries help us learn more about who lived there long ago.
question: If you wanted to learn about different theories for when people first came to North America, which section should you read?
option_1: Section 1, about Columbus and early explorers
option_2: Section 2, about Viking settlements growing
option_3: Section 3, about the Vikings being first Europeans
option_4: Section 4, about Native American arrival from Asia
option_1_explanation: Good try! This part talks about Columbus and mentions other people came first, but it doesn't tell us different ideas about when they arrived.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! This section tells us how many Vikings lived in Greenland and what they did there. It doesn't talk about different ideas for timing.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but this part is about Vikings exploring new places like Vinland. It doesn't give us different theories about when people first came.
option_4_explanation: Great job! This section gives different theories: "Some historians think" one time and "Other scientists think" another time. It's the only part with different ideas about timing.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 4's presentation of multiple scientific theories - differs from reference by requiring students to identify which section contains comparative information and multiple viewpoints rather than just the main topic of one section.
homogeneity_check: all choices are section identifiers with brief content descriptions
specificity_check: all at same level (section number plus content summary)
length_check: A: 8 words, B: 7 words, C: 8 words, D: 8 words - perfectly balanced
semantic_distance_check: each section description clearly distinct
single_correct_check: only D discusses multiple theories about timing
diversity_check: targets Section 4's comparative theories - completely different from reference and all other variants by focusing on multiple viewpoints about timing rather than population, economics, archaeology, or main topics

They think it might have been 40,000 years ago. Some experts believe these people walked across land when Alaska and Asia were connected. Others think they may have traveled along the coast in boats.
Experts think the first humans lived in Africa. About 100,000 years ago, some humans moved out of Africa and into the Middle East. About 70,000 years ago, a group of humans moved into southeast Asia. About 15,000 years ago, some of these people crossed from Asia to the Americas. Scientists believe that many people also came to North America by traveling in ships along different routes. New discoveries are made every day about early settlers in North America, and these discoveries help us learn more about who lived there long ago.

article_title: A History of People in North America
passage_text:
A History of People in North America
    
    
        Many people think that Columbus was the first person to arrive in America. But that is not correct. There are at least two other groups of people who came to North America many years before Christopher Columbus ever sailed across the ocean.
One group was the Vikings. The Vikings lived in Northern Europe, in a place called Scandinavia. They sailed around the world in their strong ships. Sometimes they would raid other places, taking things that did not belong to them. In the year 982, some Vikings left Iceland and made their homes in Greenland. Greenland is part of North America. They arrived there about 500 years before Columbus made his famous trip.

---

The Viking settlements in Greenland grew bigger over time. Scientists who study old things think there were probably 3,000 to 5,000 Viking settlers living there at one time. The Vikings had farms and made their income by raising animals and trading with other people. But after many years, the Vikings decided to leave Greenland. They had to abandon their settlements in the 1400s, not long before Columbus made his voyage.
The Vikings also explored other lands west of Greenland. Around the year 1000, a famous Viking explorer named Leif Eriksson visited a land that he and other Vikings called Vinland. Most experts believe Vinland was somewhere along the coast of Newfoundland, which is in modern-day Canada. There is strong evidence that some Vikings made settlements in Newfoundland. In 1960, scientists found the ruins of an old Viking village there. This village may have been part of Vinland.

---

The Vikings definitely reached America before Columbus did. So maybe we should say the Vikings were the first Europeans to settle in North America. But before we decide this, we need to learn about another group that came to North America.
Another group that settled in North America was the Native Americans. Even though we call these people "Native" Americans, they did not always live in the Americas. They came to America from Asia many thousands of years ago. When and how this happened is something that scientists still talk about and study.

---

Some historians think the first settlers made their way to North America a little more than 15,000 years ago. Other scientists think the first people came to America much earlier than that. They think it might have been 40,000 years ago. Some experts believe these people walked across land when Alaska and Asia were connected. Others think they may have traveled along the coast in boats.
Experts think the first humans lived in Africa. About 100,000 years ago, some humans moved out of Africa and into the Middle East. About 70,000 years ago, a group of humans moved into southeast Asia. About 15,000 years ago, some of these people crossed from Asia to the Americas. Scientists believe that many people also came to North America by traveling in ships along different routes. New discoveries are made every day about early settlers in North America, and these discoveries help us learn more about who lived there long ago.
question: What connection does the author make between the paragraphs about Viking population and Viking departure from Greenland?
option_1: The author shows that as population grew, Vikings needed to leave.
option_2: The author presents population growth, then explains they later abandoned settlements.
option_3: The author proves that population decrease caused Vikings to depart.
option_4: The author suggests Vikings left because they had too many farms.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say Vikings left because there were too many people. It tells us the settlements grew, but doesn't connect that to why they left.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The author first says settlements "grew bigger over time," then explains "they had to abandon their settlements." The story shows growth first, then leaving second.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say the Viking population got smaller or that fewer people caused them to leave. It just says they had to abandon their homes.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story mentions farms without saying there were too many. The author doesn't connect having farms to why the Vikings decided to leave Greenland.
differentiation_notes: Targets the specific connection between sentences about population and departure in Section 2 - differs from reference by examining relationship between specific adjacent paragraphs rather than overall passage organization. Requires identifying sequential connection type.
homogeneity_check: all choices describe types of connections between the two topics
specificity_check: all at same level (complete statements about paragraph relationships)
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 11 words, C: 9 words, D: 10 words - within 10% range
semantic_distance_check: each describes distinctly different types of inter-paragraph connections
single_correct_check: only B accurately identifies the sequential (not causal) connection
diversity_check: focuses on Section 2's specific inter-paragraph connection - different from reference and Variant 1 by examining relationship between adjacent specific paragraphs rather than macro organization or sectional arrangement

option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that Native Americans came "many thousands of years ago" while Vikings came much later. The author says Native Americans were first!

question: The passage states that scientists believe humans first lived in Africa and then moved to other places. Based on this information and the migration timeline given, which conclusion is best supported?
option_1: Native Americans traveled directly from Africa to North America 15,000 years ago.
option_2: Native Americans' ancestors moved through multiple continents over thousands of years before reaching North America.
option_3: Native Americans arrived in Asia at the same time Vikings arrived in Greenland.
option_4: Native Americans built ships in Africa to sail to America 100,000 years ago.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story shows people moved slowly through many places over thousands of years, not straight from Africa to America. They went to the Middle East, then Asia, then finally America.
option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says humans "moved out of Africa" first, then to other places over many thousands of years. Native Americans' families traveled through different lands before reaching America.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Vikings came to Greenland about 1,000 years ago, but Native Americans got to North America thousands of years before that. These happened at very different times.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says people left Africa 100,000 years ago and didn't reach America until much later. The story talks about walking on land, not sailing ships from Africa.
