passage_text:
Plantation Life
    
    
        Seth was playing hide-and-seek with his friends Laura, Helen, and Joseph. "Seth, it's your turn to hide," they called out. Laura was the oldest child. She said, "We'll count to thirty-three and then add five more seconds."
"Okay. Turn around now. Don't peek," said Seth. The three children turned their backs while Seth ran to find a good hiding spot. None of the children had hidden in the wagon yet. Seth ran to the wagon near the barn and crawled under a giant piece of sack cloth. Soon the three children yelled, "Ready or not, here we come!"
Seth lay very still in the wagon that was used to transport sacks of rice to town. He could hear his friends running everywhere, searching for him. This was so much fun! Slave children did not get much time to play games.

---

The children looked in the barn, in the cook's kitchen, and in the chicken coop. They did not think to look in the wagon. After searching for a long time, they gave up. "Seth, we can't find you. You can come out now," they called. But Seth did not answer. He was so warm and comfortable under the sack cloth that he had fallen asleep.
When Seth did not come out, the three children ran off to do their work. They knew that if Seth did not appear soon, he would get into a whole heap of trouble. All four children were slaves who lived on a large plantation in South Carolina in 1715. It was called the Walker Plantation. The main crop they grew was rice, and many African slaves knew how to grow rice from their homeland.
Life on the plantation was very hard. Slaves worked long hours and had to obey the plantation owner. Even though Seth was just a child, he still had many jobs to do. Every chore was important work that had to be finished.

---

While Seth slept, he thought about his two older brothers. They now worked on a different plantation that grew tobacco instead of rice. George, the older brother, had visited when their mother became sick with swamp fever. George told Seth that tobacco plantations were different from rice plantations. "On a tobacco plantation, slaves work from sunrise to sunset," George had explained. "You must tend to those tobacco leaves all the time."
Seth did not like the sound of that at all. On a rice plantation, slaves had certain jobs to finish. When they were done, they could do their own chores. But growing rice was still dangerous work. Rice grows in water, so slaves had to spend hours in swamp-like fields. The water had snakes, alligators, and insects that carried diseases. That's how Seth's mother got swamp fever.

---

The sound of a dog barking woke Seth up. He had been asleep for several hours! When he looked out from under the cloth, he saw stars twinkling in the night sky. He could smell wood burning and hear bullfrogs calling in the darkness.
"Boy am I in trouble!" Seth said as he jumped down from the wagon. He quietly walked toward the small wooden house where he lived with his parents. First, he would get a talking to from his mother and father. Then, if the field manager noticed he had not come to work in the rice fields, he might be in even bigger trouble. Seth could see his mother sewing his torn pants by candlelight. "Maybe she'll be too tired to be angry," he hoped. Seth knew he would have to admire his friends' games from far away for a long time. As he opened the door, he prepared to face his mother.
question: How will Seth most likely feel the next time he wants to play hide-and-seek with his friends?
option_1: angry
option_2: confused
option_3: excited
option_4: hesitant
option_1_explanation: Good try! Seth isn't angry though - he's worried about getting in trouble. The story shows he's scared when he says "Boy am I in trouble!"
option_2_explanation: Not quite! Seth isn't confused about what happened. He knows he fell asleep and will get in trouble for missing his work.
option_3_explanation: Close! Seth had fun playing, but now he's worried about the trouble he's in. He says "Boy am I in trouble!" which shows he's scared.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You saw that Seth is hesitant because he's worried about getting in trouble. He says "Boy am I in trouble!" and walks quietly toward home.

option_1: She is bossy and likes to control others.
option_2: She takes responsibility as the oldest child.
option_3: She is impatient and wants to play quickly.
option_4: She is competitive and wants to win games.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Laura isn't being bossy - she's helping everyone play fairly. The story shows her taking charge because she's the oldest, not because she wants to control people.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story says "Laura was the oldest child" right before she sets the rules. She takes charge of the game because that's what older kids do.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Laura actually "adds five more seconds" to the counting time. Someone who's impatient would want less time, not more time to count.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Laura isn't trying to win the game. She's helping set up the rules so everyone can play together fairly.

Seth lay very still in the wagon that was used to transport sacks of rice to town. He could hear his friends running everywhere, searching for him. This was so much fun! Slave children did not get much time to play games.

---

The children looked in the barn, in the cook's kitchen, and in the chicken coop. They did not think to look in the wagon. After searching for a long time, they gave up. "Seth, we can't find you. You can come out now," they called. But Seth did not answer. He was so warm and comfortable under the sack cloth that he had fallen asleep.
When Seth did not come out, the three children ran off to do their work. They knew that if Seth did not appear soon, he would get into a whole heap of trouble. All four children were slaves who lived on a large plantation in South Carolina in 1715. It was called the Walker Plantation. The main crop they grew was rice, and many African slaves knew how to grow rice from their homeland.
Life on the plantation was very hard. Slaves worked long hours and had to obey the plantation owner. Even though Seth was just a child, he still had many jobs to do. Every chore was important work that had to be finished.

---

While Seth slept, he thought about his two older brothers. They now worked on a different plantation that grew tobacco instead of rice. George, the older brother, had visited when their mother became sick with swamp fever. George told Seth that tobacco plantations were different from rice plantations. "On a tobacco plantation, slaves work from sunrise to sunset," George had explained. "You must tend to those tobacco leaves all the time."
Seth did not like the sound of that at all. On a rice plantation, slaves had certain jobs to finish. When they were done, they could do their own chores. But growing rice was still dangerous work. Rice grows in water, so slaves had to spend hours in swamp-like fields. The water had snakes, alligators, and insects that carried diseases. That's how Seth's mother got swamp fever.

---

The sound of a dog barking woke Seth up. He had been asleep for several hours! When he looked out from under the cloth, he saw stars twinkling in the night sky. He could smell wood burning and hear bullfrogs calling in the darkness.
"Boy am I in trouble!" Seth said as he jumped down from the wagon. He quietly walked toward the small wooden house where he lived with his parents. First, he would get a talking to from his mother and father. Then, if the field manager noticed he had not come to work in the rice fields, he might be in even bigger trouble. Seth could see his mother sewing his torn pants by candlelight. "Maybe she'll be too tired to be angry," he hoped. Seth knew he would have to admire his friends' games from far away for a long time. As he opened the door, he prepared to face his mother.
question: How does the description of Seth walking 'quietly' toward his house in paragraph 4 show his feelings?
option_1: He is exhausted from sleeping in an uncomfortable position.
option_2: He is ashamed and trying to delay facing his parents.
option_3: He is confused about what time it is.
option_4: He is proud that he won the hiding game.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says Seth was 'warm and comfortable' while sleeping. Walking quietly shows his feelings about getting in trouble, not being tired.
option_2_explanation: Great job! Seth knows he's 'in trouble' and walks quietly hoping to sneak in. He feels ashamed and wants to delay facing his angry parents.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Seth sees the 'stars twinkling' and knows it's nighttime. He's not confused about time - he's worried about punishment.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Seth says 'Boy am I in trouble!' Someone who feels proud would walk confidently, not sneak around quietly.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4 analyzing how specific word choice ('quietly') reveals Seth's emotional state - differs from reference about future feelings and focuses on present moment description
homogeneity_check: all choices are emotional/mental states explaining the behavior
specificity_check: all at similar level of emotional interpretation
length_check: A:9 words, B:9 words, C:8 words, D:8 words - within 10%
semantic_distance_check: distinct states: exhausted vs. ashamed vs. confused vs. proud
single_correct_check: only B is supported by 'Boy am I in trouble' and hoping mother is too tired to be angry
diversity_check: targets paragraph 4 and word choice analysis of 'quietly' - different from reference and other variants

option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story isn't about helping friends search. Seth learns he should have done his chores first because now "he would get into a whole heap of trouble."

option_4: Mothers worked harder than other members of slave families.

option_2_explanation: You got it! The story says Seth's mother got "swamp fever" from working in dangerous rice fields. When she got sick, it affected Seth and his whole family too.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say rice farming was the most dangerous work. It shows how the mom's sickness from her job affected her whole family.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says all slaves "worked long hours." The mom getting sick shows how dangerous work hurt the whole family, not that moms worked harder.

passage_text:
Plantation Life
    
    
        Seth was playing hide-and-seek with his friends Laura, Helen, and Joseph. "Seth, it's your turn to hide," they called out. Laura was the oldest child. She said, "We'll count to thirty-three and then add five more seconds."
"Okay. Turn around now. Don't peek," said Seth. The three children turned their backs while Seth ran to find a good hiding spot. None of the children had hidden in the wagon yet. Seth ran to the wagon near the barn and crawled under a giant piece of sack cloth. Soon the three children yelled, "Ready or not, here we come!"
Seth lay very still in the wagon that was used to transport sacks of rice to town. He could hear his friends running everywhere, searching for him. This was so much fun! Slave children did not get much time to play games.

---

The children looked in the barn, in the cook's kitchen, and in the chicken coop. They did not think to look in the wagon. After searching for a long time, they gave up. "Seth, we can't find you. You can come out now," they called. But Seth did not answer. He was so warm and comfortable under the sack cloth that he had fallen asleep.
When Seth did not come out, the three children ran off to do their work. They knew that if Seth did not appear soon, he would get into a whole heap of trouble. All four children were slaves who lived on a large plantation in South Carolina in 1715. It was called the Walker Plantation. The main crop they grew was rice, and many African slaves knew how to grow rice from their homeland.
Life on the plantation was very hard. Slaves worked long hours and had to obey the plantation owner. Even though Seth was just a child, he still had many jobs to do. Every chore was important work that had to be finished.

---

While Seth slept, he thought about his two older brothers. They now worked on a different plantation that grew tobacco instead of rice. George, the older brother, had visited when their mother became sick with swamp fever. George told Seth that tobacco plantations were different from rice plantations. "On a tobacco plantation, slaves work from sunrise to sunset," George had explained. "You must tend to those tobacco leaves all the time."
Seth did not like the sound of that at all. On a rice plantation, slaves had certain jobs to finish. When they were done, they could do their own chores. But growing rice was still dangerous work. Rice grows in water, so slaves had to spend hours in swamp-like fields. The water had snakes, alligators, and insects that carried diseases. That's how Seth's mother got swamp fever.

---

The sound of a dog barking woke Seth up. He had been asleep for several hours! When he looked out from under the cloth, he saw stars twinkling in the night sky. He could smell wood burning and hear bullfrogs calling in the darkness.
"Boy am I in trouble!" Seth said as he jumped down from the wagon. He quietly walked toward the small wooden house where he lived with his parents. First, he would get a talking to from his mother and father. Then, if the field manager noticed he had not come to work in the rice fields, he might be in even bigger trouble. Seth could see his mother sewing his torn pants by candlelight. "Maybe she'll be too tired to be angry," he hoped. Seth knew he would have to admire his friends' games from far away for a long time. As he opened the door, he prepared to face his mother.
question: Why didnt Seths friends look in the wagon when they were searching for him?
option_1: They thought Seth had already gone home.
option_2: They didn't think wagon was a hiding place.
option_3: They knew Seth was afraid of the dark places like wagons.
option_4: They didn't want to get in trouble for climbing on the wagon.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story shows they kept looking and called for Seth to come out. The text says they just didn't think to look in the wagon.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story says "They did not think to look in the wagon." You found the exact reason why they missed him!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say Seth was scared of wagons. The text shows "They did not think to look in the wagon."
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't mention getting in trouble for using the wagon. It says they just didn't think to look there.

option_4_explanation: Close! Just knowing his brother works there doesn't help Seth understand differences. It's George's explanation about "sunrise to sunset" work that teaches Seth how plantations are different.

The sound of a dog barking woke Seth up. He had been asleep for several hours! When he looked out from under the cloth, he saw stars twinkling in the night sky. He could smell wood burning and hear bullfrogs calling in the darkness.
"Boy am I in trouble!" Seth said as he jumped down from the wagon. He quietly walked toward the small wooden house where he lived with his parents. First, he would get a talking to from his mother and father. Then, if the field manager noticed he had not come to work in the rice fields, he might be in even bigger trouble. Seth could see his mother sewing his torn pants by candlelight. "Maybe she'll be too tired to be angry," he hoped. Seth knew he would have to admire his friends' games from far away for a long time. As he opened the door, he prepared to face his mother.

option_2: It compares Seth's current problem to his earlier enjoyment of the game.

option_3_explanation: Not quite! Seth thinks about consequences while walking home, not after. The paragraph shows him worrying as he goes toward home.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the paragraph doesn't list chores Seth missed. It just says he didn't work and shows him walking home worried.

passage_text:
Plantation Life
    
    
        Seth was playing hide-and-seek with his friends Laura, Helen, and Joseph. "Seth, it's your turn to hide," they called out. Laura was the oldest child. She said, "We'll count to thirty-three and then add five more seconds."
"Okay. Turn around now. Don't peek," said Seth. The three children turned their backs while Seth ran to find a good hiding spot. None of the children had hidden in the wagon yet. Seth ran to the wagon near the barn and crawled under a giant piece of sack cloth. Soon the three children yelled, "Ready or not, here we come!"
Seth lay very still in the wagon that was used to transport sacks of rice to town. He could hear his friends running everywhere, searching for him. This was so much fun! Slave children did not get much time to play games.

---

The children looked in the barn, in the cook's kitchen, and in the chicken coop. They did not think to look in the wagon. After searching for a long time, they gave up. "Seth, we can't find you. You can come out now," they called. But Seth did not answer. He was so warm and comfortable under the sack cloth that he had fallen asleep.
When Seth did not come out, the three children ran off to do their work. They knew that if Seth did not appear soon, he would get into a whole heap of trouble. All four children were slaves who lived on a large plantation in South Carolina in 1715. It was called the Walker Plantation. The main crop they grew was rice, and many African slaves knew how to grow rice from their homeland.
Life on the plantation was very hard. Slaves worked long hours and had to obey the plantation owner. Even though Seth was just a child, he still had many jobs to do. Every chore was important work that had to be finished.

---

While Seth slept, he thought about his two older brothers. They now worked on a different plantation that grew tobacco instead of rice. George, the older brother, had visited when their mother became sick with swamp fever. George told Seth that tobacco plantations were different from rice plantations. "On a tobacco plantation, slaves work from sunrise to sunset," George had explained. "You must tend to those tobacco leaves all the time."
Seth did not like the sound of that at all. On a rice plantation, slaves had certain jobs to finish. When they were done, they could do their own chores. But growing rice was still dangerous work. Rice grows in water, so slaves had to spend hours in swamp-like fields. The water had snakes, alligators, and insects that carried diseases. That's how Seth's mother got swamp fever.

---

The sound of a dog barking woke Seth up. He had been asleep for several hours! When he looked out from under the cloth, he saw stars twinkling in the night sky. He could smell wood burning and hear bullfrogs calling in the darkness.
"Boy am I in trouble!" Seth said as he jumped down from the wagon. He quietly walked toward the small wooden house where he lived with his parents. First, he would get a talking to from his mother and father. Then, if the field manager noticed he had not come to work in the rice fields, he might be in even bigger trouble. Seth could see his mother sewing his torn pants by candlelight. "Maybe she'll be too tired to be angry," he hoped. Seth knew he would have to admire his friends' games from far away for a long time. As he opened the door, he prepared to face his mother.

option_1: Seth has learned to take responsibility for his mistakes.
option_2: Seth is more worried about his mother than the field manager.
option_3: Seth believes his mother will understand and forgive him quickly.
option_4: Seth knows his mother is the strictest person on the plantation.
option_1_explanation: Great job! When Seth 'prepares to face his mother,' he's not hiding or making excuses. This shows he knows he made a mistake and will accept the consequences.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story says Seth worries about both his mother AND the field manager getting upset. He doesn't worry more about one than the other.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Seth hopes his mother might be 'too tired to be angry,' but he still knows he's in big trouble. He doesn't expect her to forgive him quickly.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't compare his mother to other people on the plantation. It's about Seth being ready to face the trouble he's in.

passage_text:
Early Days in Georgia
    
    
        Hello, my name is Sarah. My family and I are from England. We have been in Savannah, Georgia, for five years now. We left England in November 1737 on a sailing ship called the Anne. It took us two months to reach these shores. I will never forget how bitterly cold it was on the deck of the ship. The wind stung my face like an angry bee. The waves were dark, gray, and scary. They tossed our ship around everywhere. I was afraid those giant waves would devour us completely.
Our first stop in North America was Charleston. After that, we traveled to the town where I now live called Savannah. Savannah is in the English colony of Georgia. It's not quite a real town yet, like the ones back in England, but it will be someday. When we first arrived in Savannah, my mother called it a wilderness. I was six years old then. Now I am eleven.

---

Mr. James Oglethorpe and twenty-one other English gentlemen had been granted a charter by King George II of England. The charter gave them permission to create an English colony under English law. The charter says that they are the trustees, or governors, of this colony. This means they are in charge. However, everyone knows that it is really Mr. Oglethorpe who makes all the decisions. I have also heard that Mr. Oglethorpe wants this colony to succeed so much that he sold some of his own property in England to earn money for Georgia.
Mr. Oglethorpe is a personal friend of the king. He convinced the king to create this colony. My father said that Mr. Oglethorpe intends to bring debtors here too. When I asked him what debtors were, he told me that they are people who owe money to other people. This money they owe is called debt. Often debtors go to jail until they can pay off their debts. They can even die in jail. Mr. Oglethorpe wants some of these people to be given a second chance here in Georgia.

---

My parents aren't debtors. They were chosen by Mr. Oglethorpe for their skills. My father is a carpenter and my mother is a seamstress. Mr. Oglethorpe wanted mostly skilled people to come to Savannah. He said that would be the only way we would survive here. The grownups talk about what happened to the first settlers in Virginia. Some of them died because they were not skilled enough. Many others died because of cold and hunger. So Mr. Oglethorpe and the other trustees chose mostly farmers, merchants, bakers, carpenters, and blacksmiths to be the first English colonists here.
When we first arrived in Savannah, we lived in tents. There were forty families altogether. We worked very hard to build the wall that now surrounds us. Inside the wall, we built our homes. Everyone worked, even the children. Slowly, our town began to take shape.

---

Mr. Oglethorpe made friends with the chief of a local tribe called the Yamacraw. The chief's name is Tomochichi. Tomochichi even traveled back to England with Mr. Oglethorpe to get more supplies for us. Tomochichi and his people trust us for now. However, I have heard some of the boys saying that the Spanish to the south of us are our main enemy. They want this land. The Spanish have a large fort called St. Augustine in Spanish Florida. They could attack us at any time. Because of this threat, Mr. Oglethorpe has returned to England to ask King George II for soldiers to help protect us.
I must go now. I hear my mother calling me. I have to help her prepare the evening meal.
question: Sarah's family traveled to Georgia to help build
option_1: a farm.
option_2: a fort.
option_3: a school.
option_4: a colony.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say they came to build a farm. The text says Sarah lives in "the English colony of Georgia."
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says Sarah lives in "the English colony of Georgia." They came to build a colony, not a fort.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story never mentions building a school. It says they got permission "to create an English colony."
option_4_explanation: Great job! The story says "the English colony of Georgia" and they got permission "to create an English colony."

---

Mr. James Oglethorpe and twenty-one other English gentlemen had been granted a charter by King George II of England. The charter gave them permission to create an English colony under English law. The charter says that they are the trustees, or governors, of this colony. This means they are in charge. However, everyone knows that it is really Mr. Oglethorpe who makes all the decisions. I have also heard that Mr. Oglethorpe wants this colony to succeed so much that he sold some of his own property in England to earn money for Georgia.
Mr. Oglethorpe is a personal friend of the king. He convinced the king to create this colony. My father said that Mr. Oglethorpe intends to bring debtors here too. When I asked him what debtors were, he told me that they are people who owe money to other people. This money they owe is called debt. Often debtors go to jail until they can pay off their debts. They can even die in jail. Mr. Oglethorpe wants some of these people to be given a second chance here in Georgia.

---

My parents aren't debtors. They were chosen by Mr. Oglethorpe for their skills. My father is a carpenter and my mother is a seamstress. Mr. Oglethorpe wanted mostly skilled people to come to Savannah. He said that would be the only way we would survive here. The grownups talk about what happened to the first settlers in Virginia. Some of them died because they were not skilled enough. Many others died because of cold and hunger. So Mr. Oglethorpe and the other trustees chose mostly farmers, merchants, bakers, carpenters, and blacksmiths to be the first English colonists here.
When we first arrived in Savannah, we lived in tents. There were forty families altogether. We worked very hard to build the wall that now surrounds us. Inside the wall, we built our homes. Everyone worked, even the children. Slowly, our town began to take shape.

---

Mr. Oglethorpe made friends with the chief of a local tribe called the Yamacraw. The chief's name is Tomochichi. Tomochichi even traveled back to England with Mr. Oglethorpe to get more supplies for us. Tomochichi and his people trust us for now. However, I have heard some of the boys saying that the Spanish to the south of us are our main enemy. They want this land. The Spanish have a large fort called St. Augustine in Spanish Florida. They could attack us at any time. Because of this threat, Mr. Oglethorpe has returned to England to ask King George II for soldiers to help protect us.
I must go now. I hear my mother calling me. I have to help her prepare the evening meal.

passage_text:
Early Days in Georgia
    
    
        Hello, my name is Sarah. My family and I are from England. We have been in Savannah, Georgia, for five years now. We left England in November 1737 on a sailing ship called the Anne. It took us two months to reach these shores. I will never forget how bitterly cold it was on the deck of the ship. The wind stung my face like an angry bee. The waves were dark, gray, and scary. They tossed our ship around everywhere. I was afraid those giant waves would devour us completely.
Our first stop in North America was Charleston. After that, we traveled to the town where I now live called Savannah. Savannah is in the English colony of Georgia. It's not quite a real town yet, like the ones back in England, but it will be someday. When we first arrived in Savannah, my mother called it a wilderness. I was six years old then. Now I am eleven.

---

Mr. James Oglethorpe and twenty-one other English gentlemen had been granted a charter by King George II of England. The charter gave them permission to create an English colony under English law. The charter says that they are the trustees, or governors, of this colony. This means they are in charge. However, everyone knows that it is really Mr. Oglethorpe who makes all the decisions. I have also heard that Mr. Oglethorpe wants this colony to succeed so much that he sold some of his own property in England to earn money for Georgia.
Mr. Oglethorpe is a personal friend of the king. He convinced the king to create this colony. My father said that Mr. Oglethorpe intends to bring debtors here too. When I asked him what debtors were, he told me that they are people who owe money to other people. This money they owe is called debt. Often debtors go to jail until they can pay off their debts. They can even die in jail. Mr. Oglethorpe wants some of these people to be given a second chance here in Georgia.

---

My parents aren't debtors. They were chosen by Mr. Oglethorpe for their skills. My father is a carpenter and my mother is a seamstress. Mr. Oglethorpe wanted mostly skilled people to come to Savannah. He said that would be the only way we would survive here. The grownups talk about what happened to the first settlers in Virginia. Some of them died because they were not skilled enough. Many others died because of cold and hunger. So Mr. Oglethorpe and the other trustees chose mostly farmers, merchants, bakers, carpenters, and blacksmiths to be the first English colonists here.
When we first arrived in Savannah, we lived in tents. There were forty families altogether. We worked very hard to build the wall that now surrounds us. Inside the wall, we built our homes. Everyone worked, even the children. Slowly, our town began to take shape.

---

Mr. Oglethorpe made friends with the chief of a local tribe called the Yamacraw. The chief's name is Tomochichi. Tomochichi even traveled back to England with Mr. Oglethorpe to get more supplies for us. Tomochichi and his people trust us for now. However, I have heard some of the boys saying that the Spanish to the south of us are our main enemy. They want this land. The Spanish have a large fort called St. Augustine in Spanish Florida. They could attack us at any time. Because of this threat, Mr. Oglethorpe has returned to England to ask King George II for soldiers to help protect us.
I must go now. I hear my mother calling me. I have to help her prepare the evening meal.
question: Look at the text. Which word best describes the picture Sarah creates of her ocean journey?
option_1: exciting
option_2: boring
option_3: peaceful
option_4: frightening
option_1_explanation: Good try! A sea trip might sound fun, but Sarah says she was "afraid those giant waves would devour us." The story shows she felt scared, not excited.
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the trip wasn't quiet or slow. Sarah describes "scary" waves and says she was "afraid." The journey was frightening, not boring.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The ocean part wasn't calm because Sarah felt "afraid those giant waves would devour us." She describes scary waves, so it was frightening.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right feeling by reading Sarah's words about being "afraid those giant waves would devour us." The scary details show it was frightening.

Tomochichi even traveled back to England with Mr. Oglethorpe to get more supplies for us. Tomochichi and his people trust us for now. However, I have heard some of the boys saying that the Spanish to the south of us are our main enemy. They want this land. The Spanish have a large fort called St. Augustine in Spanish Florida. They could attack us at any time. Because of this threat, Mr. Oglethorpe has returned to England to ask King George II for soldiers to help protect us.
I must go now. I hear my mother calling me. I have to help her prepare the evening meal.

passage_text:
Early Days in Georgia
    
    
        Hello, my name is Sarah. My family and I are from England. We have been in Savannah, Georgia, for five years now. We left England in November 1737 on a sailing ship called the Anne. It took us two months to reach these shores. I will never forget how bitterly cold it was on the deck of the ship. The wind stung my face like an angry bee. The waves were dark, gray, and scary. They tossed our ship around everywhere. I was afraid those giant waves would devour us completely.
Our first stop in North America was Charleston. After that, we traveled to the town where I now live called Savannah. Savannah is in the English colony of Georgia. It's not quite a real town yet, like the ones back in England, but it will be someday. When we first arrived in Savannah, my mother called it a wilderness. I was six years old then. Now I am eleven.

---

Mr. James Oglethorpe and twenty-one other English gentlemen had been granted a charter by King George II of England. The charter gave them permission to create an English colony under English law. The charter says that they are the trustees, or governors, of this colony. This means they are in charge. However, everyone knows that it is really Mr. Oglethorpe who makes all the decisions. I have also heard that Mr. Oglethorpe wants this colony to succeed so much that he sold some of his own property in England to earn money for Georgia.
Mr. Oglethorpe is a personal friend of the king. He convinced the king to create this colony. My father said that Mr. Oglethorpe intends to bring debtors here too. When I asked him what debtors were, he told me that they are people who owe money to other people. This money they owe is called debt. Often debtors go to jail until they can pay off their debts. They can even die in jail. Mr. Oglethorpe wants some of these people to be given a second chance here in Georgia.

---

My parents aren't debtors. They were chosen by Mr. Oglethorpe for their skills. My father is a carpenter and my mother is a seamstress. Mr. Oglethorpe wanted mostly skilled people to come to Savannah. He said that would be the only way we would survive here. The grownups talk about what happened to the first settlers in Virginia. Some of them died because they were not skilled enough. Many others died because of cold and hunger. So Mr. Oglethorpe and the other trustees chose mostly farmers, merchants, bakers, carpenters, and blacksmiths to be the first English colonists here.
When we first arrived in Savannah, we lived in tents. There were forty families altogether. We worked very hard to build the wall that now surrounds us. Inside the wall, we built our homes. Everyone worked, even the children. Slowly, our town began to take shape.

---

Mr. Oglethorpe made friends with the chief of a local tribe called the Yamacraw. The chief's name is Tomochichi. Tomochichi even traveled back to England with Mr. Oglethorpe to get more supplies for us. Tomochichi and his people trust us for now. However, I have heard some of the boys saying that the Spanish to the south of us are our main enemy. They want this land. The Spanish have a large fort called St. Augustine in Spanish Florida. They could attack us at any time. Because of this threat, Mr. Oglethorpe has returned to England to ask King George II for soldiers to help protect us.
I must go now. I hear my mother calling me. I have to help her prepare the evening meal.

option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the Spanish soldiers were a problem for Georgia, not Virginia. The Virginia settlers had trouble because they lacked survival skills.
option_4_explanation: Close! The story mentions cold, but it says the real problem was "they were not skilled enough" to handle tough conditions.

passage_text:
The Pilgrims, Part I: Arrival
    
    
        Mary and Remember Allerton ran as fast as they could toward their house. Their stepmother, Mrs. Fear Allerton, was waiting for them. As their father had said many times, it was not smart to keep a woman whose name was Fear waiting.
That afternoon, the children had gone out to collect firewood. After gathering the wood, they had stopped to play in the forest with their friends, Love and Wrestling Brewster. Love and Wrestling were Pilgrim brothers who had also come to collect firewood. Like many Pilgrim children, these children had been given special names at birth. Their names often indicate what kind of person their parents hoped they would become.
Remember had been given her name because her mother said she would always remember her birth. Wrestling wasn't happy with his name. He didn't feel like a wrestler at all. Wrestling planned to change his name to John when he got older. He had been a weak baby, and his father gave him the name hoping it would make him strong.

---

The children had gathered firewood and dropped it in a large pile to play hide and seek. They climbed trees and collected sweet berries to eat. They pretended to be English pirates capturing Spanish ships filled with gold. When the sun began to set, they realized they had been gone for a long time. The children anxiously gathered up their firewood and hurried home.
Four years earlier, all four children had survived the journey on the Mayflower from England. They had arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts, in 1621. Their parents were English Separatists. English Separatists were people who were unhappy with the Church of England and wanted to start their own church. They wanted to be free to worship God in their own way.

---

The king of England, James I, was the head of the Church of England. He would harass anyone who did not follow the church rules. This was a threat to the English Separatists. As a result, many English Separatists left England. The children's families had first tried living in the Netherlands, but they were not happy there. Finally, they set out across the Atlantic Ocean to start their own colony in North America. Because they were willing to travel to a faraway place for their religious beliefs, they began calling themselves Pilgrims.
The journey across the ocean and the first winter in the colony was now just a terrible memory. So many people had died either on the ship or within the first months in Plymouth. They died from sickness, hunger, and extremely cold weather. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had to witness the death of many Pilgrims. Worst of all was the death of the girls' beloved mother.

---

After their mother died, their father tried to comfort them as best he could. The girls felt that their hearts were broken. Their brother Bartholomew had hidden in the forest for several days. He refused to come back no matter how often they called his name. When spring arrived, Bartholomew helped their father build a house and plant crops.
The Pilgrims had not planned to settle in Plymouth. They had been planning to go to Virginia, but their ship had been blown off course. When they finally arrived, it was winter and they were in an unknown land hundreds of miles north of where they wanted to go. This place was much colder than Virginia, and the soil was not very good for farming. The children's new home was not at all what they had imagined it would be.
question: This passage is best described as
option_1: a folktale
option_2: a historical fiction story
option_3: a biography
option_4: a diary entry
option_1_explanation: Good try! This story has real history like "the Mayflower" and Plymouth, not magic or talking animals like folktales. It's made-up characters in a real time from history.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You spotted that this mixes real history like "the journey on the Mayflower" with made-up characters like Mary and Remember. That's exactly what historical fiction does!
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but biographies tell about one real person's whole life. This story follows made-up kids like "Mary and Remember" playing games in historical times.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Diaries use words like "I" and "Dear Diary," but this says "Mary and Remember ran" like a storyteller. It's a made-up story set long ago.

The journey across the ocean and the first winter in the colony was now just a terrible memory. So many people had died either on the ship or within the first months in Plymouth. They died from sickness, hunger, and extremely cold weather. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had to witness the death of many Pilgrims. Worst of all was the death of the girls' beloved mother.

---

After their mother died, their father tried to comfort them as best he could. The girls felt that their hearts were broken. Their brother Bartholomew had hidden in the forest for several days. He refused to come back no matter how often they called his name. When spring arrived, Bartholomew helped their father build a house and plant crops.
The Pilgrims had not planned to settle in Plymouth. They had been planning to go to Virginia, but their ship had been blown off course. When they finally arrived, it was winter and they were in an unknown land hundreds of miles north of where they wanted to go. This place was much colder than Virginia, and the soil was not very good for farming. The children's new home was not at all what they had imagined it would be.

passage_text:

        Mary and Remember Allerton ran as fast as they could toward their house. Their stepmother, Mrs. Fear Allerton, was waiting for them. As their father had said many times, it was not smart to keep a woman whose name was Fear waiting.

---

They pretended to be English pirates capturing Spanish ships filled with gold. When the sun began to set, they realized they had been gone for a long time. question: According to the passage, what was the main reason the children's families left England to live in the Netherlands?
option_1: They wanted to worship in their own way without being punished.
option_2: They hoped to find treasure like pirates.
option_3: All the farmland in England had gone bad.
option_4: They planned a short visit with friends and stayed for fun.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that they "wanted to be free to worship God in their own way." The king would punish people who didn't follow his church rules.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The kids pretended to be pirates, but that was just a game. The story says the real reason was about worshipping God their own way.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the bad soil was in their new home, not England. The story says they left England because they wanted to worship without being punished.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The kids had fun playing, but their families came for a serious reason. They wanted to worship God without the king punishing them.

English Separatists were people who were unhappy with the Church of England and wanted to start their own church. They wanted to be free to worship God in their own way.

---

The king of England, James I, was the head of the Church of England. He would harass anyone who did not follow the church rules. This was a threat to the English Separatists. As a result, many English Separatists left England. The children's families had first tried living in the Netherlands, but they were not happy there. Finally, they set out across the Atlantic Ocean to start their own colony in North America. Because they were willing to travel to a faraway place for their religious beliefs, they began calling themselves Pilgrims.
The journey across the ocean and the first winter in the colony was now just a terrible memory. So many people had died either on the ship or within the first months in Plymouth. They died from sickness, hunger, and extremely cold weather. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had to witness the death of many Pilgrims. Worst of all was the death of the girls' beloved mother.

---

After their mother died, their father tried to comfort them as best he could. The girls felt that their hearts were broken. Their brother Bartholomew had hidden in the forest for several days. He refused to come back no matter how often they called his name. When spring arrived, Bartholomew helped their father build a house and plant crops.
The Pilgrims had not planned to settle in Plymouth. They had been planning to go to Virginia, but their ship had been blown off course. When they finally arrived, it was winter and they were in an unknown land hundreds of miles north of where they wanted to go. This place was much colder than Virginia, and the soil was not very good for farming. The children's new home was not at all what they had imagined it would be.

option_1: They wanted to avoid doing their chores at home.

option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but they weren't hiding from Fear. They played because they met friends, then realized they'd been gone too long and hurried home.

option_2: to emphasize the personal tragedy the children experienced
option_3: to explain why the family left England in the first place

The king of England, James I, was the head of the Church of England. He would harass anyone who did not follow the church rules. This was a threat to the English Separatists. As a result, many English Separatists left England. The children's families had first tried living in the Netherlands, but they were not happy there. Finally, they set out across the Atlantic Ocean to start their own colony in North America. Because they were willing to travel to a faraway place for their religious beliefs, they began calling themselves Pilgrims.
The journey across the ocean and the first winter in the colony was now just a terrible memory. So many people had died either on the ship or within the first months in Plymouth. They died from sickness, hunger, and extremely cold weather. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had to witness the death of many Pilgrims. Worst of all was the death of the girls' beloved mother.

---

After their mother died, their father tried to comfort them as best he could. The girls felt that their hearts were broken. Their brother Bartholomew had hidden in the forest for several days. He refused to come back no matter how often they called his name. When spring arrived, Bartholomew helped their father build a house and plant crops.
The Pilgrims had not planned to settle in Plymouth. They had been planning to go to Virginia, but their ship had been blown off course. When they finally arrived, it was winter and they were in an unknown land hundreds of miles north of where they wanted to go. This place was much colder than Virginia, and the soil was not very good for farming. The children's new home was not at all what they had imagined it would be.
question: How does the author help readers understand the narrator's view of the Pilgrims' experience?
option_1: by describing only the happy moments of playing in the forest
option_2: by presenting both the children's joy and their hardships
option_3: by focusing entirely on the religious conflicts in England
option_4: by explaining the ship's navigation problems in detail

option_2_explanation: You got it! The author shows both fun times like "playing hide and seek" and hard times like death and cold. This helps us see the whole picture.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story mentions why they left England, but it talks about many other things too like the trip, playing, and daily life. It doesn't focus 'entirely' on one thing.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story only mentions the ship going off course quickly. The author doesn't explain ship problems 'in detail' - just talks about what happened after.

passage_text:
The Pilgrims, Part I: Arrival
    
    
        Mary and Remember Allerton ran as fast as they could toward their house. Their stepmother, Mrs. Fear Allerton, was waiting for them. As their father had said many times, it was not smart to keep a woman whose name was Fear waiting.
That afternoon, the children had gone out to collect firewood. After gathering the wood, they had stopped to play in the forest with their friends, Love and Wrestling Brewster. Love and Wrestling were Pilgrim brothers who had also come to collect firewood. Like many Pilgrim children, these children had been given special names at birth. Their names often indicate what kind of person their parents hoped they would become.
Remember had been given her name because her mother said she would always remember her birth. Wrestling wasn't happy with his name. He didn't feel like a wrestler at all. Wrestling planned to change his name to John when he got older. He had been a weak baby, and his father gave him the name hoping it would make him strong.

---

The children had gathered firewood and dropped it in a large pile to play hide and seek. They climbed trees and collected sweet berries to eat. They pretended to be English pirates capturing Spanish ships filled with gold. When the sun began to set, they realized they had been gone for a long time. The children anxiously gathered up their firewood and hurried home.
Four years earlier, all four children had survived the journey on the Mayflower from England. They had arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts, in 1621. Their parents were English Separatists. English Separatists were people who were unhappy with the Church of England and wanted to start their own church. They wanted to be free to worship God in their own way.

---

When they finally arrived, it was winter and they were in an unknown land hundreds of miles north of where they wanted to go. question: Based on the passage, what perspective does the author want readers to have about the children?
option_1: The children were careless and irresponsible about their duties.
option_2: The children showed strength by finding joy despite tragedy.
option_3: The children were more interested in games than in their family.
option_4: The children never recovered from their difficult experiences.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The children did finish getting firewood before playing and "anxiously gathered up their firewood" when they remembered to go home. They just lost track of time having fun.
option_2_explanation: Exactly! Even after losing their mom and other sad times, the children still played games and had fun together. The story shows they were strong and could still find happiness.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the children really cared about their family - their "hearts were broken" when their mom died. Playing with friends doesn't mean they loved their family less.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story shows the children are getting better - they play, laugh, and do their chores. They're healing from the sad things that happened to them.

specificity_check: all at interpretive perspective level

single_correct_check: only B is defensible based on author's balanced presentation
diversity_check: targets author's intended perspective on characters throughout passage - different from narrative technique, word choice analysis, and all content-based questions

article_title: The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
passage_text:
The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
    
    
        Do you remember the Pilgrim children Mary and Remember Allerton and Love and Wrestling Brewster? In the last chapter, they were collecting firewood and playing in the forest. Then you learned how they arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts. In this chapter, we will find out more about their early life in Plymouth.
Years earlier, when the children and other Pilgrims arrived in Plymouth in 1621, they were not alone. Native Americans had watched them from the forest. They watched as these foreigners worked to build shelters during the day and returned to their ship at night to sleep. They watched as the newcomers shivered in the cold. They watched as they buried their dead in the quiet of the night. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had watched too, and wondered if they would survive.

---

Although there were many hardships, two things helped them survive. A native tribe called the Patuxet had lived in the area and created fields for planting. Sadly, many members of this tribe had died because they caught diseases from European explorers. Because of this, their fields were empty. This meant that the hungry English colonists did not have to clear the forests before planting time.
A Native American called Squanto came to help the Pilgrims. His friend Samoset helped too. Both men spoke English very well. In 1605, Squanto had been taken to England by an English explorer. Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims how to plant corn, squash, and beans. They taught them how to make crops grow in the poor soil. Squanto also taught people which berries and fruits were safe to eat and where the best fishing spots were. Wrestling Brewster often said he had feared these people at first, but when they helped the settlers, he changed his mind.

---

The colonists also made peace with a local tribe called the Wampanoag. Both sides agreed to help and protect each other. They agreed to trade with each other too. This meant the colonists could build their homes without fear of attack.
Slowly, the days grew warmer and the Pilgrims became happier. The first fall was one of the most precious memories the children had. The crops had grown well and their harvest was abundant. The colonists had also learned how to hunt and fish in this new land. They had produced more than enough food to get through the next winter. They had built homes that would protect them from cold weather. While they mourned those who had died, the surviving colonists were thankful for what they had. That is why they decided to give thanks to God and the native people who had helped them.

---

A great celebration of thanksgiving was organized. The local Wampanoag were invited to the thanksgiving celebration. Squanto and Samoset were invited too. The Wampanoag chief, Massasoit, was the guest of honor. Everyone dined on deer, duck, lobster, fish, cornbread, pumpkin, squash, and berries. They played games and ran races. The Wampanoag stayed in the colony for several days. It was probably the happiest time the children could remember.
Since then, more Pilgrims had arrived. More homes had been built. Their father had married Mistress Fear. All these early experiences happened four years ago. Now the children were playing in a forest in a new world. Even though the Mayflower had gone off course from its original destination, Plymouth had become their home. As Mary and Remember hurried out of the forest, they said goodbye to Love and Wrestling. Minutes later they arrived at their house door. Mistress Fear appeared in the doorway with her hands on her hips, ready to scold them for being late with the firewood.
question: Why did Wrestling Brewster change his mind about the Native Americans?
option_1: They were invited to dinner.
option_2: They lived in the forest.
option_3: They spoke English well.
option_4: They helped the settlers.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The Native Americans were invited to dinner later, but that's not why Wrestling changed his mind. The story says they "helped the settlers" by teaching them important things first.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The story says Native Americans watched from the forest, but doesn't say they lived there. Wrestling changed his mind because "they helped the settlers" with planting and fishing.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but speaking English was just one detail. Wrestling changed his mind because the Native Americans "helped the settlers" by teaching them how to grow food and find fish.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer because "Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims" many helpful things. Wrestling changed his mind when he saw how much they helped.

article_title: The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
passage_text:
The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
    
    
        Do you remember the Pilgrim children Mary and Remember Allerton and Love and Wrestling Brewster? In the last chapter, they were collecting firewood and playing in the forest. Then you learned how they arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts. In this chapter, we will find out more about their early life in Plymouth.
Years earlier, when the children and other Pilgrims arrived in Plymouth in 1621, they were not alone. Native Americans had watched them from the forest. They watched as these foreigners worked to build shelters during the day and returned to their ship at night to sleep. They watched as the newcomers shivered in the cold. They watched as they buried their dead in the quiet of the night. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had watched too, and wondered if they would survive.

---

Although there were many hardships, two things helped them survive. A native tribe called the Patuxet had lived in the area and created fields for planting. Sadly, many members of this tribe had died because they caught diseases from European explorers. Because of this, their fields were empty. This meant that the hungry English colonists did not have to clear the forests before planting time.
A Native American called Squanto came to help the Pilgrims. His friend Samoset helped too. Both men spoke English very well. In 1605, Squanto had been taken to England by an English explorer. Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims how to plant corn, squash, and beans. They taught them how to make crops grow in the poor soil. Squanto also taught people which berries and fruits were safe to eat and where the best fishing spots were. Wrestling Brewster often said he had feared these people at first, but when they helped the settlers, he changed his mind.

---

The colonists also made peace with a local tribe called the Wampanoag. Both sides agreed to help and protect each other. They agreed to trade with each other too. This meant the colonists could build their homes without fear of attack.
Slowly, the days grew warmer and the Pilgrims became happier. The first fall was one of the most precious memories the children had. The crops had grown well and their harvest was abundant. The colonists had also learned how to hunt and fish in this new land. They had produced more than enough food to get through the next winter. They had built homes that would protect them from cold weather. While they mourned those who had died, the surviving colonists were thankful for what they had. That is why they decided to give thanks to God and the native people who had helped them.

---

A great celebration of thanksgiving was organized. The local Wampanoag were invited to the thanksgiving celebration. Squanto and Samoset were invited too. The Wampanoag chief, Massasoit, was the guest of honor. Everyone dined on deer, duck, lobster, fish, cornbread, pumpkin, squash, and berries. They played games and ran races. The Wampanoag stayed in the colony for several days. It was probably the happiest time the children could remember.
Since then, more Pilgrims had arrived. More homes had been built. Their father had married Mistress Fear. All these early experiences happened four years ago. Now the children were playing in a forest in a new world. Even though the Mayflower had gone off course from its original destination, Plymouth had become their home. As Mary and Remember hurried out of the forest, they said goodbye to Love and Wrestling. Minutes later they arrived at their house door. Mistress Fear appeared in the doorway with her hands on her hips, ready to scold them for being late with the firewood.
question: According to the passage, what made the colonists decide to have a thanksgiving celebration?
option_1: They wanted to meet the Wampanoag chief.
option_2: They were grateful for their food and help received.
option_3: They needed to use their abundant harvest quickly.
option_4: They wanted to practice their hunting skills.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say they wanted to meet the chief. The chief was invited after they already decided to celebrate.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The colonists were "thankful for what they had." They wanted to give thanks for their food and help.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say they needed to use food quickly. They had enough food to last through winter.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't mention hunting skills as a reason. They wanted to celebrate because they were thankful.
differentiation_notes: Targets paragraph 4-5 about the reason for organizing the thanksgiving - differs from reference which asks about Wrestling's character development
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential motivations or reasons for having the celebration
specificity_check: all describe possible purposes for organizing an event
length_check: A: 8 words, B: 9 words, C: 8 words, D: 7 words - balanced within 15%
semantic_distance_check: each choice presents distinctly different motivations with no overlap
single_correct_check: only B is defensible as the explicitly stated reason in the text
diversity_check: targets paragraphs 4-5 about celebration motivation - completely different from reference and all other variants

question: Which sentence best states the central message of the story?
option_1: Working together and sharing knowledge helps in hard times.
option_2: Strong leaders always keep people from getting lost on long trips.
option_3: The Pilgrims learned to plant, hunt, and fish.
option_4: Building sturdy houses keeps out the winter cold.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found the main idea by seeing that "Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims" how to survive. The story is all about people helping each other through tough times.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story mentions the ship going off course, but it's mostly about Native Americans helping the Pilgrims. The main idea is about working together, not staying on track.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's just one detail! Yes, they learned to plant and hunt, but the whole story shows how Native Americans and Pilgrims helped each other survive.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Houses are mentioned, but the story focuses on how "Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims" what to do. It's about people helping people, not just building homes.

A great celebration of thanksgiving was organized. The local Wampanoag were invited to the thanksgiving celebration. Squanto and Samoset were invited too. The Wampanoag chief, Massasoit, was the guest of honor. Everyone dined on deer, duck, lobster, fish, cornbread, pumpkin, squash, and berries. They played games and ran races. The Wampanoag stayed in the colony for several days. It was probably the happiest time the children could remember.
Since then, more Pilgrims had arrived. More homes had been built. Their father had married Mistress Fear. All these early experiences happened four years ago. Now the children were playing in a forest in a new world. Even though the Mayflower had gone off course from its original destination, Plymouth had become their home. As Mary and Remember hurried out of the forest, they said goodbye to Love and Wrestling. Minutes later they arrived at their house door. Mistress Fear appeared in the doorway with her hands on her hips, ready to scold them for being late with the firewood.

article_title: The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
passage_text:
The Pilgrims, Part II: Thanksgiving Celebration
    
    
        Do you remember the Pilgrim children Mary and Remember Allerton and Love and Wrestling Brewster? In the last chapter, they were collecting firewood and playing in the forest. Then you learned how they arrived in Plymouth, Massachusetts. In this chapter, we will find out more about their early life in Plymouth.
Years earlier, when the children and other Pilgrims arrived in Plymouth in 1621, they were not alone. Native Americans had watched them from the forest. They watched as these foreigners worked to build shelters during the day and returned to their ship at night to sleep. They watched as the newcomers shivered in the cold. They watched as they buried their dead in the quiet of the night. Mary, Remember, Love, and Wrestling had watched too, and wondered if they would survive.

---

Although there were many hardships, two things helped them survive. A native tribe called the Patuxet had lived in the area and created fields for planting. Sadly, many members of this tribe had died because they caught diseases from European explorers. Because of this, their fields were empty. This meant that the hungry English colonists did not have to clear the forests before planting time.
A Native American called Squanto came to help the Pilgrims. His friend Samoset helped too. Both men spoke English very well. In 1605, Squanto had been taken to England by an English explorer. Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims how to plant corn, squash, and beans. They taught them how to make crops grow in the poor soil. Squanto also taught people which berries and fruits were safe to eat and where the best fishing spots were. Wrestling Brewster often said he had feared these people at first, but when they helped the settlers, he changed his mind.

---

The colonists also made peace with a local tribe called the Wampanoag. Both sides agreed to help and protect each other. They agreed to trade with each other too. This meant the colonists could build their homes without fear of attack.
Slowly, the days grew warmer and the Pilgrims became happier. The first fall was one of the most precious memories the children had. The crops had grown well and their harvest was abundant. The colonists had also learned how to hunt and fish in this new land. They had produced more than enough food to get through the next winter. They had built homes that would protect them from cold weather. While they mourned those who had died, the surviving colonists were thankful for what they had. That is why they decided to give thanks to God and the native people who had helped them.

---

A great celebration of thanksgiving was organized. The local Wampanoag were invited to the thanksgiving celebration. Squanto and Samoset were invited too. The Wampanoag chief, Massasoit, was the guest of honor. Everyone dined on deer, duck, lobster, fish, cornbread, pumpkin, squash, and berries. They played games and ran races. The Wampanoag stayed in the colony for several days. It was probably the happiest time the children could remember.
Since then, more Pilgrims had arrived. More homes had been built. Their father had married Mistress Fear. All these early experiences happened four years ago. Now the children were playing in a forest in a new world. Even though the Mayflower had gone off course from its original destination, Plymouth had become their home. As Mary and Remember hurried out of the forest, they said goodbye to Love and Wrestling. Minutes later they arrived at their house door. Mistress Fear appeared in the doorway with her hands on her hips, ready to scold them for being late with the firewood.

option_1: They bought it from English explorers.

option_4: They found it stored in Native American villages.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say English explorers sold food to the Pilgrims. The Pilgrims had to grow and find their own food.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The story says the Pilgrims "learned how to hunt and fish" and grew crops. They got food by working hard themselves.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The Mayflower ship isn't mentioned giving food to the Pilgrims. They had to grow crops and learn to hunt instead.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say they found stored food in villages. The fields were empty when they arrived.

Although there were many hardships, two things helped them survive. A native tribe called the Patuxet had lived in the area and created fields for planting. Sadly, many members of this tribe had died because they caught diseases from European explorers. Because of this, their fields were empty. This meant that the hungry English colonists did not have to clear the forests before planting time.
A Native American called Squanto came to help the Pilgrims. His friend Samoset helped too. Both men spoke English very well. In 1605, Squanto had been taken to England by an English explorer. Squanto and Samoset showed the Pilgrims how to plant corn, squash, and beans. They taught them how to make crops grow in the poor soil. Squanto also taught people which berries and fruits were safe to eat and where the best fishing spots were. Wrestling Brewster often said he had feared these people at first, but when they helped the settlers, he changed his mind.

---

The colonists also made peace with a local tribe called the Wampanoag. Both sides agreed to help and protect each other. They agreed to trade with each other too. This meant the colonists could build their homes without fear of attack.
Slowly, the days grew warmer and the Pilgrims became happier. The first fall was one of the most precious memories the children had. The crops had grown well and their harvest was abundant. The colonists had also learned how to hunt and fish in this new land. They had produced more than enough food to get through the next winter. They had built homes that would protect them from cold weather. While they mourned those who had died, the surviving colonists were thankful for what they had. That is why they decided to give thanks to God and the native people who had helped them.

---

A great celebration of thanksgiving was organized. The local Wampanoag were invited to the thanksgiving celebration. Squanto and Samoset were invited too. The Wampanoag chief, Massasoit, was the guest of honor. Everyone dined on deer, duck, lobster, fish, cornbread, pumpkin, squash, and berries. They played games and ran races. The Wampanoag stayed in the colony for several days. It was probably the happiest time the children could remember.
Since then, more Pilgrims had arrived. More homes had been built. Their father had married Mistress Fear. All these early experiences happened four years ago. Now the children were playing in a forest in a new world. Even though the Mayflower had gone off course from its original destination, Plymouth had become their home. As Mary and Remember hurried out of the forest, they said goodbye to Love and Wrestling. Minutes later they arrived at their house door. Mistress Fear appeared in the doorway with her hands on her hips, ready to scold them for being late with the firewood.

passage_text:
Puritan Life
    
    
        Hello, my name is Lizzie. I am a Puritan child living in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. My mother and father are upset with me again. I smiled too much during the morning sermon, and then I fell asleep during the afternoon sermon. They said it is a great sin for a Puritan child to fall asleep while listening to God's word from the Bible.
During the morning sermon, I smiled when I saw Elder Jones's new wig. I could not understand why a minister of the church would want to wear such a strange thing on his head. It did not sit straight and looked very funny. When I smiled and pointed at him, my mother pinched me so hard that my leg still hurts. I know I must mend my ways and be better.

---

The most important place for any Puritan is the meeting house. Every meeting house sits in the center of our town. That is because the meeting house is the center of our lives. Our church services happen there, and so do all important meetings. The Elder likes to preach there for many hours.
We Puritans live in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Our colony works with the Massachusetts Bay Company. The company sells the fur we get from hunting and the fish we catch. Our colony is becoming wealthy because of this trading. We came here from England in 1630 when I was just a baby. Now I am almost eleven years old. Unlike the Pilgrims, we did not want to break away from the Church of England. We wanted the church to be more pure and stronger. But King James I and his son King Charles I would not listen to us. We had no choice but to leave our homeland and start a new life. We chose to create our own colony north of Plymouth. Our leader John Winthrop guided us to this new land.

---

Trade ships often come in and out of our harbor. I love to watch the men unload items sent from across the ocean. We need guns, tools, and cloth. We hear news from home by talking to sailors and new colonists. It makes our hearts flutter when they talk about life in England. Just two months ago, I sat on the snow-covered dock and listened to stories from home. The sailors spoke of the glorious sound of London church bells ringing on Christmas Day. They told us about the smell of roasting pheasant and sweet plum pudding. Some of us feel homesick, but we know our cause is good and worth the sacrifice.

---

People are welcome here, but all who come must live by the rules of the Bible. That is the Puritan way. My brother George keeps pulling my hair and running away. I have asked him to stop, but he continues. My mother and father had seven children, but George and I are the only two still alive. They make excuses for George's behavior because he is only four years old, but not for mine. I must be "responsible Lizzie."
It seems Elder Jones is not done yet. He has called us back to the meeting house for one more sermon before sunset. I hope he is not wearing that funny wig again. There is no mill nearby, so we must grind our grain by hand, which takes much time.
question: In this story, the main problem is that Lizzie
option_1: is not following Puritan rules during church.
option_2: cannot understand the minister's sermons.
option_3: does not want to live in the colony.
option_4: is too young to attend the meeting house.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that Lizzie broke church rules when she "smiled too much" and "fell asleep" during sermons. Her parents said this was a sin.
option_2_explanation: Good try! Lizzie didn't understand the wig, not the sermon. The story shows she broke church rules by smiling and sleeping during sermons.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say Lizzie wants to leave the colony. Her parents are upset because she misbehaved in church.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! Lizzie is eleven and goes to church with her family. Her parents are mad because she smiled and slept during sermons.

It did not sit straight and looked very funny. When I smiled and pointed at him, my mother pinched me so hard that my leg still hurts. I know I must mend my ways and be better.

---

The most important place for any Puritan is the meeting house. Every meeting house sits in the center of our town. That is because the meeting house is the center of our lives. Our church services happen there, and so do all important meetings. The Elder likes to preach there for many hours.
We Puritans live in the Massachusetts Bay Colony. Our colony works with the Massachusetts Bay Company. The company sells the fur we get from hunting and the fish we catch. Our colony is becoming wealthy because of this trading. We came here from England in 1630 when I was just a baby. Now I am almost eleven years old. Unlike the Pilgrims, we did not want to break away from the Church of England. We wanted the church to be more pure and stronger. But King James I and his son King Charles I would not listen to us. We had no choice but to leave our homeland and start a new life. We chose to create our own colony north of Plymouth. Our leader John Winthrop guided us to this new land.

---

Trade ships often come in and out of our harbor. I love to watch the men unload items sent from across the ocean. We need guns, tools, and cloth. We hear news from home by talking to sailors and new colonists. It makes our hearts flutter when they talk about life in England. Just two months ago, I sat on the snow-covered dock and listened to stories from home. The sailors spoke of the glorious sound of London church bells ringing on Christmas Day. They told us about the smell of roasting pheasant and sweet plum pudding. Some of us feel homesick, but we know our cause is good and worth the sacrifice.

---

People are welcome here, but all who come must live by the rules of the Bible. That is the Puritan way. My brother George keeps pulling my hair and running away. I have asked him to stop, but he continues. My mother and father had seven children, but George and I are the only two still alive. They make excuses for George's behavior because he is only four years old, but not for mine. I must be "responsible Lizzie."
It seems Elder Jones is not done yet. He has called us back to the meeting house for one more sermon before sunset. I hope he is not wearing that funny wig again. There is no mill nearby, so we must grind our grain by hand, which takes much time.

option_2: George pulls Lizzie's hair and runs away without getting punished.
option_3: Lizzie's parents say falling asleep during a sermon is a great sin.

option_3_explanation: You got it! The story says falling asleep during a sermon is "a great sin." Calling sleep a great sin shows Puritans had very strict religious rules.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! This talks about selling fur and fish to make money. That's about business, not about the strict religious rules Puritans had to follow.

question: The passage describes Lizzie as someone who must 'mend my ways and be better.' What character trait does this phrase reveal about Lizzie?
option_1: She recognizes when she makes mistakes and wants to improve.
option_2: She enjoys fixing broken items around the colony.
option_3: She prefers to blame others instead of herself.
option_4: She thinks the Puritan rules are completely wrong.
option_1_explanation: You got it! When Lizzie says "I must mend my ways and be better," she knows she made mistakes and wants to do better next time.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The word "mend" here doesn't mean fixing broken things. Lizzie is talking about fixing her behavior, not objects around the colony.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Lizzie doesn't blame anyone else for her mistakes. She says "I know I must" change, which shows she takes responsibility.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but Lizzie doesn't think the rules are wrong. She wants to follow them better and says she needs to improve her behavior.
