Millions of years and countless floods later, the land in Petrified Forest National Park has worn away. We are left with this strange landscape. It is still called a forest, but many of the trees are really rocks. The land is almost like a desert now. However, the Petrified Forest does get some rain. There is actually a lot happening in this ecosystem, even though it looks like a dry, sandy place.
There are 500 different types of plants in Petrified Forest National Park. There are no dinosaurs, but there are little lizards. There are also toads, snakes, birds, and jackrabbits. Coyotes are near the top of the food chain. They eat just about anything, meat and plants alike. The Petrified Forest shows how nature's forces can change the landscape. When the land changes, the ecosystem changes too. There were once forests and swamps here. Now, it is a rocky desert. But it is still an ecosystem! Through all the changes, there has always been life here. Living things find a way to survive, even when they face extinction.
question: Based on the entire passage, what lesson does nature teach us about life?
option_1: Living things find ways to survive even when environments change dramatically.
option_2: Floods always destroy ecosystems so completely that nothing can live there again.
option_3: Deserts are better places for animals to live than forests or swamps.
option_4: Once an environment changes, it will always stay exactly the same forever.
option_1_explanation: Great job! The story shows that even after huge changes, "there has always been life here." Living things keep finding ways to survive.
option_2_explanation: Good try! But the story shows that after floods destroyed the old forest, a new desert grew with 500 different plants and animals.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say which places are better for animals. It shows that animals live in different places and adapt.
option_4_explanation: Close! But the story shows environments keep changing - from swamps to buried forests to desert. Things don't stay the same.

Coyotes are near the top of the food chain. They eat just about anything, meat and plants alike. The Petrified Forest shows how nature's forces can change the landscape. passage_text:
Natural Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Ecosystems can be fragile. It doesn't take much to cause big changes in the environment. Sometimes the ecosystem can recover from a change. Sometimes the change lasts forever.
One common force of nature is when land wears away. Over time, the land on both sides of a stream can erode. When it rains really hard, a little stream can fill with water and flood. A flood may last for an hour. It may last for a few days.
Plants on a hillside have roots that reach deep into the soil. The roots hold the soil together. When it rains, or when the wind blows really hard, the plant roots hold the soil in place. Without plants, the soil starts to erode.

---

Water is one of nature's most powerful forces. During a big flood, the entire landscape can be changed. A flooded river can tear apart plants, trees, and soil. First, the topsoil is removed. This is the richest soil, where you find most of the nutrients and matter that is starting to decay. Once the topsoil is washed away, the forces of nature slowly eat away at the clay and rock underneath.
There is a place called Petrified Forest National Park in Arizona. Throughout the park, there are ancient trees that have turned to stone. The trees have been petrified! These may look like normal rocks, but they're not! There was a forest ecosystem here about 200 million years ago. This was during prehistoric times, when some of the first dinosaurs walked on Earth. These rocks are actually pieces of very old trees!

---

Back then, there were plants, animals, and tiny living things that helped matter decay. Scientists have found fossils in the Petrified Forest. These show that there were swamp plants, like ferns. There were also dinosaurs that looked sort of like crocodiles.
At some point, the area was flooded by huge amounts of water and mud. The trees were covered completely. The entire forest was destroyed, along with the food chain. All that mud covering the trees dried up. Over millions of years, the mud turned to rock. Instead of rotting away, the trees turned to rock, too!

---

Millions of years and countless floods later, the land in Petrified Forest National Park has worn away. We are left with this strange landscape. It is still called a forest, but many of the trees are really rocks. The land is almost like a desert now. However, the Petrified Forest does get some rain. There is actually a lot happening in this ecosystem, even though it looks like a dry, sandy place.
There are 500 different types of plants in Petrified Forest National Park. There are no dinosaurs, but there are little lizards. There are also toads, snakes, birds, and jackrabbits. Coyotes are near the top of the food chain. They eat just about anything, meat and plants alike. The Petrified Forest shows how nature's forces can change the landscape. When the land changes, the ecosystem changes too. There were once forests and swamps here. Now, it is a rocky desert. But it is still an ecosystem! Through all the changes, there has always been life here. Living things find a way to survive, even when they face extinction.

passage_text:
Human Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Every plant and animal in nature needs other living things to survive. A butterfly needs flowers for food. At the same time, flowers need butterflies to spread their pollen from plant to plant.
Long ago, early humans were part of nature too. They hunted animals and gathered plants for food. They made homes and clothes from things they found around them. Most importantly, they only used what they needed to stay alive.
But humans were different from other animals. They could make and use technology. At first, they made simple tools from stone and wood. These tools helped them hunt better and build stronger shelters.

---

Over time, technology got much better. Humans learned to make machines. Instead of hunting wild animals, they learned to raise cows and chickens for food. Instead of gathering berries and nuts, they learned to grow their own crops. Humans learned to change and control parts of nature to meet their needs.
With technology, humans could change the environment in countless ways. A wheat field may have once been a forest or grassland. Insects and other living things still live in the soil and eat the wheat plants. But this is not a natural field anymore. Humans planted the seeds and decide when to harvest the crops.
Every town and city was once a natural place where many species of plants and animals lived. Then humans used technology to change these natural places. There are still some trees and flowers in cities, but only because people put them there. Some animals like squirrels and birds learned to live in cities with humans.

---

Today, with all our cities and technology, we sometimes forget about nature. We think of nature as something we can visit, not something we are part of. We think of nature as a resource we can use and change however we want.
The Hoover Dam shows how people can change nature. This huge dam was built across the Colorado River. The dam can generate hydroelectric power, or electricity, for over a million people. The reservoir created by the dam gives water to thousands of homes and farms. The river is the source of this water and power.
The Hoover Dam helps people, but it also changed the river forever. It changed how the river flows and put several species of fish and plants in danger. passage_text:
Human Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Every plant and animal in nature needs other living things to survive. A butterfly needs flowers for food. At the same time, flowers need butterflies to spread their pollen from plant to plant.
Long ago, early humans were part of nature too. They hunted animals and gathered plants for food. They made homes and clothes from things they found around them. Most importantly, they only used what they needed to stay alive.
But humans were different from other animals. They could make and use technology. At first, they made simple tools from stone and wood. These tools helped them hunt better and build stronger shelters.

---

Over time, technology got much better. Humans learned to make machines. Instead of hunting wild animals, they learned to raise cows and chickens for food. Instead of gathering berries and nuts, they learned to grow their own crops. Humans learned to change and control parts of nature to meet their needs.
With technology, humans could change the environment in countless ways. A wheat field may have once been a forest or grassland. Insects and other living things still live in the soil and eat the wheat plants. But this is not a natural field anymore. Humans planted the seeds and decide when to harvest the crops.
Every town and city was once a natural place where many species of plants and animals lived. Then humans used technology to change these natural places. There are still some trees and flowers in cities, but only because people put them there. Some animals like squirrels and birds learned to live in cities with humans.

---

Today, with all our cities and technology, we sometimes forget about nature. We think of nature as something we can visit, not something we are part of. We think of nature as a resource we can use and change however we want.
The Hoover Dam shows how people can change nature. This huge dam was built across the Colorado River. The dam can generate hydroelectric power, or electricity, for over a million people. The reservoir created by the dam gives water to thousands of homes and farms. The river is the source of this water and power.
The Hoover Dam helps people, but it also changed the river forever. It changed how the river flows and put several species of fish and plants in danger. Some of these species became endangered, which means they might disappear completely. The dam was good for people but not good for the environment.

---

Not all changes that humans make are bad for nature. People can live good lives while still protecting the balance of nature. A small town surrounded by forests shows this. People have their houses and roads, but most of the land around them still belongs to nature. Even a jackrabbit can find safe places to live near the town.
People use nature primarily to meet their needs, but we can learn to do this without hurting the environment. We can protect the countless species that share our world while still using natural resources wisely.

passage_text:
Human Changes to the Environment
    
    
        Every plant and animal in nature needs other living things to survive. A butterfly needs flowers for food. At the same time, flowers need butterflies to spread their pollen from plant to plant.
Long ago, early humans were part of nature too. They hunted animals and gathered plants for food. They made homes and clothes from things they found around them. Most importantly, they only used what they needed to stay alive.
But humans were different from other animals. They could make and use technology. At first, they made simple tools from stone and wood. These tools helped them hunt better and build stronger shelters.

---

Over time, technology got much better. Humans learned to make machines. Instead of hunting wild animals, they learned to raise cows and chickens for food. Instead of gathering berries and nuts, they learned to grow their own crops. Humans learned to change and control parts of nature to meet their needs.
With technology, humans could change the environment in countless ways. A wheat field may have once been a forest or grassland. Insects and other living things still live in the soil and eat the wheat plants. But this is not a natural field anymore. Humans planted the seeds and decide when to harvest the crops.
Every town and city was once a natural place where many species of plants and animals lived. Then humans used technology to change these natural places. There are still some trees and flowers in cities, but only because people put them there. Some animals like squirrels and birds learned to live in cities with humans.

---

Today, with all our cities and technology, we sometimes forget about nature. We think of nature as something we can visit, not something we are part of. We think of nature as a resource we can use and change however we want.
The Hoover Dam shows how people can change nature. This huge dam was built across the Colorado River. The dam can generate hydroelectric power, or electricity, for over a million people. The reservoir created by the dam gives water to thousands of homes and farms. The river is the source of this water and power.
The Hoover Dam helps people, but it also changed the river forever. It changed how the river flows and put several species of fish and plants in danger. Some of these species became endangered, which means they might disappear completely. The dam was good for people but not good for the environment.

---

Not all changes that humans make are bad for nature. People can live good lives while still protecting the balance of nature. A small town surrounded by forests shows this. People have their houses and roads, but most of the land around them still belongs to nature. Even a jackrabbit can find safe places to live near the town.
People use nature primarily to meet their needs, but we can learn to do this without hurting the environment. We can protect the countless species that share our world while still using natural resources wisely.
question: What is the most likely reason the author includes the example of a small town surrounded by forests in Section 4?
option_1: to show that humans can meet needs while protecting nature
option_2: to argue that all people should move to small towns
option_3: to explain why jackrabbits are endangered species
option_4: to prove that forests are better than cities
option_1_explanation: You got it! The author shows the small town to prove that "people can live good lives while still protecting nature."
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say everyone should move to small towns. It just shows one example of balance.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The jackrabbits aren't in danger - they "can find safe places to live" near town.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author isn't saying forests are better than cities. The story shows towns AND forests together.

passage_text:
Environmental Damage Caused by Humans
    
    
        Most vehicles you see every day need gasoline to work. Cars, boats, trains, and planes all use gasoline for energy. When a car's engine burns gasoline, it makes the car move. Gasoline comes from oil, which is a thick, black liquid found deep underground in certain places on Earth.
Getting oil out of the ground is very hard work. People drill deep wells into the earth. These wells pump oil up from underground. Thousands of oil wells around the world are used to get oil from deep in the ground.
Much oil is located deep beneath ocean waters. Workers use a special platform called an oil rig. The oil rig floats far out in the ocean. Dozens of workers live on the oil rig for months at a time. They use special drills to get oil from hundreds or thousands of feet beneath the ocean surface.

---

Unfortunately, drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous. This danger became real on April 20, 2010, when a terrible accident happened. An oil rig called the Deepwater Horizon was working in the Gulf of Mexico, about 40 miles off the coast of Louisiana. An important piece of equipment deep underwater broke. This allowed oil and natural gases to escape from the earth. The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.
The Deepwater Horizon was destroyed by the explosion and fire. Sadly, 11 men died in the explosion and 16 others were badly hurt. But this was not the end of the story. The disaster that followed was a massive oil spill.
When the rig exploded, oil began flowing freely from inside the earth. Because it was so far underwater, nobody knew how to stop the oil. Within days, the waters near the damaged well were heavily polluted with thick, black oil. Oil continued to spill into the water for three months, and the oil quickly spread across the ocean.

---

The ocean ecosystem is fragile. Everything from tiny organisms to plants and fish need clean water to survive. The oil threatened fish and all other life in the nearby waters. Within days, oil from the oil spill washed up all along the Gulf Coast of the United States. The oil reached beaches in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. The oil threatened the lives of fish, birds, and other wildlife in or near the water.
The grassy, shallow wetlands along the Gulf Coast are home to a fragile ecosystem with a huge variety of wildlife. People were especially worried about the effect oil might have on this area. In the wetlands, you can find shellfish like oysters, crabs, and shrimp. Many birds live there, including herons, pelicans, and egrets. Reptiles such as alligators and snakes also live in the Gulf Coast wetlands. All of these animals can be harmed if they get covered in oil or eat other animals covered in oil.

---

The wetlands are very important for people too. They provide seafood like the shrimp you might eat in a restaurant. The wetlands are important for other reasons as well. The grass roots keep sand and soil in place. If the grasses get covered in oil, they could die. Then the sand and soil would wash away. As a result, the coastline could erode, which would harm nearby towns and cities.
Oil from the oil spill was a threat to life at sea and on land, including people. This was a huge problem, and everyone knew something had to be done to protect the wetlands and wildlife from the oil. People worked hard to save the Gulf Coast from this terrible disaster.
question: Read the excerpt from Section 2. 'The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.' The phrase escaping gases caused shows that the gases were
option_1: expected.
option_2: contained.
option_3: helpful.
option_4: dangerous.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The story says it was an "accident" and "Unfortunately," which means it wasn't expected. The gases were dangerous because they caused an explosion.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! If the gases were contained, they wouldn't escape and cause an explosion. The story shows the gases were dangerous when they got out.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the gases weren't helpful here. The story says "drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous" and the gases caused an explosion that hurt people.
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading that "drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous." The escaping gases caused an explosion, which shows they were dangerous.

Environmental Damage Caused by Humans
    
    
        Most vehicles you see every day need gasoline to work. Cars, boats, trains, and planes all use gasoline for energy. When a car's engine burns gasoline, it makes the car move. Gasoline comes from oil, which is a thick, black liquid found deep underground in certain places on Earth.
Getting oil out of the ground is very hard work. People drill deep wells into the earth. These wells pump oil up from underground. Thousands of oil wells around the world are used to get oil from deep in the ground.
Much oil is located deep beneath ocean waters. Workers use a special platform called an oil rig. The oil rig floats far out in the ocean. Dozens of workers live on the oil rig for months at a time. They use special drills to get oil from hundreds or thousands of feet beneath the ocean surface.

---

Unfortunately, drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous. This danger became real on April 20, 2010, when a terrible accident happened. An oil rig called the Deepwater Horizon was working in the Gulf of Mexico, about 40 miles off the coast of Louisiana. An important piece of equipment deep underwater broke. This allowed oil and natural gases to escape from the earth. The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.
The Deepwater Horizon was destroyed by the explosion and fire. Sadly, 11 men died in the explosion and 16 others were badly hurt. But this was not the end of the story. The disaster that followed was a massive oil spill.
When the rig exploded, oil began flowing freely from inside the earth. Because it was so far underwater, nobody knew how to stop the oil. Within days, the waters near the damaged well were heavily polluted with thick, black oil. Oil continued to spill into the water for three months, and the oil quickly spread across the ocean.

---

The ocean ecosystem is fragile. Everything from tiny organisms to plants and fish need clean water to survive. The oil threatened fish and all other life in the nearby waters. Within days, oil from the oil spill washed up all along the Gulf Coast of the United States. The oil reached beaches in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. The oil threatened the lives of fish, birds, and other wildlife in or near the water.
The grassy, shallow wetlands along the Gulf Coast are home to a fragile ecosystem with a huge variety of wildlife. People were especially worried about the effect oil might have on this area. In the wetlands, you can find shellfish like oysters, crabs, and shrimp. Many birds live there, including herons, pelicans, and egrets. Reptiles such as alligators and snakes also live in the Gulf Coast wetlands. All of these animals can be harmed if they get covered in oil or eat other animals covered in oil.

---

The wetlands are very important for people too. They provide seafood like the shrimp you might eat in a restaurant. The wetlands are important for other reasons as well. The grass roots keep sand and soil in place. If the grasses get covered in oil, they could die. Then the sand and soil would wash away. As a result, the coastline could erode, which would harm nearby towns and cities.
Oil from the oil spill was a threat to life at sea and on land, including people. This was a huge problem, and everyone knew something had to be done to protect the wetlands and wildlife from the oil. People worked hard to save the Gulf Coast from this terrible disaster.
question: Based on Section 1, what relationship does the text show between gasoline and oil?
option_1: Gasoline is made from oil.
option_2: Gasoline is used to find oil.
option_3: Gasoline is stored inside oil.
option_4: Gasoline is heavier than oil.
option_1_explanation: You got it! The story says "Gasoline comes from oil." This means gasoline is made from oil.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't say gasoline helps find oil. It says cars use gasoline, but oil workers don't use gasoline to find oil.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but gasoline isn't stored inside oil. The story says gasoline "comes from" oil, which means it's made from oil.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't tell us which one weighs more. It only tells us that gasoline comes from oil.
differentiation_notes: Targets Section 1 relationship between gasoline and oil (production/source) - differs from reference about cause-effect in Section 2 explosion

specificity_check: all provide specific connections between the two substances

single_correct_check: only A matches text 'gasoline comes from oil'
diversity_check: targets Section 1 gasoline-oil relationship - completely different from reference Section 2 explosion cause-effect and other variants

question: Why is the Gulf Coast location important to this disaster?
option_1: Many different ecosystems are at risk there.
option_2: People need the ocean for transportation.
option_3: The wetlands make cleanup very difficult.
option_4: Oil rigs only work in the Gulf of Mexico.
option_1_explanation: Great job! You found that the oil spill hurt "fish and all other life" in many different places. The story shows the oil damaged both ocean animals and wetland animals.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The story doesn't talk about people using boats to travel. It focuses on how the oil spill hurt "fish and all other life" in different ecosystems.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say cleanup was hard because of wetlands. It shows that oil hurt many different places with "fragile ecosystems" like oceans and wetlands.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story says oil rigs work "around the world," not just in the Gulf. The important thing is that many different ecosystems were hurt by the spill.

Much oil is located deep beneath ocean waters. Workers use a special platform called an oil rig. The oil rig floats far out in the ocean. Dozens of workers live on the oil rig for months at a time. They use special drills to get oil from hundreds or thousands of feet beneath the ocean surface.

---

Unfortunately, drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous. This danger became real on April 20, 2010, when a terrible accident happened. An oil rig called the Deepwater Horizon was working in the Gulf of Mexico, about 40 miles off the coast of Louisiana. An important piece of equipment deep underwater broke. This allowed oil and natural gases to escape from the earth. The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.
The Deepwater Horizon was destroyed by the explosion and fire. Sadly, 11 men died in the explosion and 16 others were badly hurt. But this was not the end of the story. The disaster that followed was a massive oil spill.
When the rig exploded, oil began flowing freely from inside the earth. Because it was so far underwater, nobody knew how to stop the oil. Within days, the waters near the damaged well were heavily polluted with thick, black oil. Oil continued to spill into the water for three months, and the oil quickly spread across the ocean.

---

The ocean ecosystem is fragile. Everything from tiny organisms to plants and fish need clean water to survive. The oil threatened fish and all other life in the nearby waters. Within days, oil from the oil spill washed up all along the Gulf Coast of the United States. The oil reached beaches in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. The oil threatened the lives of fish, birds, and other wildlife in or near the water.
The grassy, shallow wetlands along the Gulf Coast are home to a fragile ecosystem with a huge variety of wildlife. People were especially worried about the effect oil might have on this area. In the wetlands, you can find shellfish like oysters, crabs, and shrimp. Many birds live there, including herons, pelicans, and egrets. Reptiles such as alligators and snakes also live in the Gulf Coast wetlands. All of these animals can be harmed if they get covered in oil or eat other animals covered in oil.

---

The wetlands are very important for people too. They provide seafood like the shrimp you might eat in a restaurant. The wetlands are important for other reasons as well. The grass roots keep sand and soil in place. If the grasses get covered in oil, they could die. Then the sand and soil would wash away. As a result, the coastline could erode, which would harm nearby towns and cities.
Oil from the oil spill was a threat to life at sea and on land, including people. This was a huge problem, and everyone knew something had to be done to protect the wetlands and wildlife from the oil. People worked hard to save the Gulf Coast from this terrible disaster.
question: According to the passage, what do wetland animals, coastal towns, and the seafood industry all have in common?
option_1: They all depend on oil rigs for survival.
option_2: They were all threatened by the oil spill.
option_3: They all exist deep underwater.
option_4: They all require gasoline to function.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Oil rigs don't help these things survive - they actually hurt them. The story shows how the oil spill damaged all three.
option_2_explanation: Great job! The oil spill "threatened the lives" of animals, hurt the seafood business, and could damage coastal towns. They all faced danger from the same disaster.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Towns are on land, not underwater. Only some of the animals and seafood live in water.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story doesn't say these things need gasoline. The oil spill is what connects all three together.

specificity_check: all state specific shared characteristics

single_correct_check: only B accurately identifies what text says all three share
diversity_check: requires cross-section synthesis finding common threat to multiple entities - different from reference and all previous variants

question: Which event happened long after the oil rig exploded?
option_1: Oil began pouring out of the well into the ocean.
option_2: Oil washed up on beaches along the Gulf Coast.
option_3: The equipment deep underwater broke.
option_4: Trapped gas built up and caused the explosion.
option_1_explanation: Good try! Oil pouring from the well happened right when the rig exploded. The story says oil "washed up all along the Gulf Coast" days later at the beaches.
option_2_explanation: Great job! You found what happened after the explosion. The story says oil "washed up all along the Gulf Coast" which means it reached the beaches later.
option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but the broken equipment happened before the explosion, not after. The story tells us oil reached the Gulf Coast beaches days later.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The gas explosion happened first and caused the accident. The story says oil reached the beaches "within days" after the explosion.

option_4_explanation: Not quite! This tells what happened before the explosion, but the question asks what happened after it exploded.

Environmental Damage Caused by Humans
    
    
        Most vehicles you see every day need gasoline to work. Cars, boats, trains, and planes all use gasoline for energy. When a car's engine burns gasoline, it makes the car move. Gasoline comes from oil, which is a thick, black liquid found deep underground in certain places on Earth.
Getting oil out of the ground is very hard work. People drill deep wells into the earth. These wells pump oil up from underground. Thousands of oil wells around the world are used to get oil from deep in the ground.
Much oil is located deep beneath ocean waters. Workers use a special platform called an oil rig. The oil rig floats far out in the ocean. Dozens of workers live on the oil rig for months at a time. They use special drills to get oil from hundreds or thousands of feet beneath the ocean surface.

---

Unfortunately, drilling for oil is difficult and dangerous. This danger became real on April 20, 2010, when a terrible accident happened. An oil rig called the Deepwater Horizon was working in the Gulf of Mexico, about 40 miles off the coast of Louisiana. An important piece of equipment deep underwater broke. This allowed oil and natural gases to escape from the earth. The escaping gases caused a huge explosion on the oil rig.
The Deepwater Horizon was destroyed by the explosion and fire. Sadly, 11 men died in the explosion and 16 others were badly hurt. But this was not the end of the story. The disaster that followed was a massive oil spill.
When the rig exploded, oil began flowing freely from inside the earth. Because it was so far underwater, nobody knew how to stop the oil. Within days, the waters near the damaged well were heavily polluted with thick, black oil. Oil continued to spill into the water for three months, and the oil quickly spread across the ocean.

---

The ocean ecosystem is fragile. Everything from tiny organisms to plants and fish need clean water to survive. The oil threatened fish and all other life in the nearby waters. Within days, oil from the oil spill washed up all along the Gulf Coast of the United States. The oil reached beaches in Texas, Louisiana, Mississippi, Alabama, and Florida. The oil threatened the lives of fish, birds, and other wildlife in or near the water.
The grassy, shallow wetlands along the Gulf Coast are home to a fragile ecosystem with a huge variety of wildlife. People were especially worried about the effect oil might have on this area. In the wetlands, you can find shellfish like oysters, crabs, and shrimp. Many birds live there, including herons, pelicans, and egrets. Reptiles such as alligators and snakes also live in the Gulf Coast wetlands. All of these animals can be harmed if they get covered in oil or eat other animals covered in oil.

---

The wetlands are very important for people too. They provide seafood like the shrimp you might eat in a restaurant. The wetlands are important for other reasons as well. The grass roots keep sand and soil in place. If the grasses get covered in oil, they could die. Then the sand and soil would wash away. As a result, the coastline could erode, which would harm nearby towns and cities.
Oil from the oil spill was a threat to life at sea and on land, including people. This was a huge problem, and everyone knew something had to be done to protect the wetlands and wildlife from the oil. People worked hard to save the Gulf Coast from this terrible disaster.
question: Based on the passage, what would most likely have happened if the Deepwater Horizon had been drilling on land instead of in the ocean?
option_1: The oil spill would have been easier to stop and contain.
option_2: The explosion would have been prevented completely.
option_3: More workers would have been injured in the accident.
option_4: The oil would have spread to more states.
option_1_explanation: You got it! The story says drilling underwater made it hard to stop the oil spill. On land, workers could reach the broken parts much easier.
option_2_explanation: Good try! The explosion happened because equipment broke, not because it was in the ocean. The same break could happen on land too.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say land drilling hurts more workers. On land, it might actually be safer to help people.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the ocean water carried oil to many beaches. On land, the oil couldn't spread as far to other states.
differentiation_notes: Requires hypothetical reasoning about changed conditions (land vs ocean location) based on Section 2 information about underwater difficulty - differs from reference about wetland grass dying
homogeneity_check: all choices are potential consequences of land-based drilling
specificity_check: all predict specific different outcomes
length_check: A: 11 words, B: 7 words, C: 9 words, D: 9 words - B slightly shorter but within reasonable range
semantic_distance_check: distinct outcomes: easier containment vs prevention vs more injuries vs wider spread
single_correct_check: only A follows logically from text about underwater access problems
diversity_check: requires hypothetical reasoning about location change - different from reference about grass consequences and all previous variants

option_1: The coastline would erode and harm nearby towns
option_2: More oil rigs would be built in the Gulf of Mexico

option_4: People would stop eating seafood from restaurants

option_3_explanation: Nice thinking, but that's just how oil rigs work normally. The story explains what happens to the coastline when wetland grasses die from oil.
option_4_explanation: Not quite! The story doesn't say people would stop eating seafood. Look for what happens to the coastline when the grasses die.

option_2: Workers would develop better safety equipment for rigs.

option_4: Ocean drilling would become easier and less expensive.

option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but the question asks what would happen to nature if oil kept spilling for years. Better safety tools might happen later, but that's not about the environment.

passage_text:
Protecting the Environment
    
    
        After three months of hard work, engineers and scientists from around the world finally stopped the oil spill from the Deepwater Horizon oil rig. They were able to seal the well so no more oil could leak into the ocean water.
During those difficult months, many people worked to protect the waters and beaches around the Gulf of Mexico. One of the first things they did was spread oil booms in the water. An oil boom is like a floating wall that stops oil from spreading. Workers placed these oil booms all along the coast to keep oil away from beaches and wetlands. Once the oil was trapped by the oil booms, special boats came to clean the oil out of the water.

---

Even with all this work, thousands of gallons of oil still washed up on land. Workers spent many months cleaning oil from the beaches. Thanks to lots of hard work, people were able to prevent a complete environmental disaster. We will never know exactly how many fish, shrimp, and other sea animals died from the oil spill, but it could have been much worse. Most importantly, most of the wetlands were saved.
There are many things you can do to help protect the environment. To make things we use every day like bottles, cans, and paper, we need to use a natural resource. A natural resource is something from nature that people use to make products. To make cans, people dig mines and remove metals like aluminum from the earth. Trees are a natural resource used to make paper. Plastic bottles and toys are made from oil, which is also a natural resource.

---

Cans, bottles, and papers can be used again when we recycle them. When you recycle, old items get turned into new ones. This means we need less metal from mines, fewer trees get cut down, and less oil gets used to make new plastic. When we recycle, we help protect the environment!
Today there are over 7 billion people on Earth. About half of all the land is used to grow food for everyone. Towns, cities, and roads cover much of the remaining land. This does not leave much room for forests and other natural places where animals live.

---

People are finding smart ways to protect nature while still using its resources. Tree farms are one example. At a tree farm, workers cut down trees in one section while new trees grow in another section. This way, people can get the wood they need without cutting down all the forests.
People are also working to find cleaner ways to make electricity for homes and schools. Today, most electricity comes from oil and coal. Getting these fuels can cause accidents like oil spills. But we can also use wind and sunlight to make electricity. Giant windmills at wind farms create clean, safe electricity. It is possible to protect the environment and still get all the food and energy we need to live healthy lives.
question: Which of these is most like an oil boom?
option_1: a special boat
option_2: a tree farm
option_3: a metal can
option_4: a floating wall
option_1_explanation: Good try! Special boats did help clean up oil, but they're not the same as oil booms. The story says oil booms are "like a floating wall."
option_2_explanation: Nice thinking, but tree farms aren't oil booms. The story tells us an oil boom is "like a floating wall that stops oil from spreading."
option_3_explanation: Not quite! Metal cans are mentioned later in the story, but oil booms are different. The story says they're "like a floating wall."
option_4_explanation: Great job! You found the right answer by reading carefully. The story says an oil boom is "like a floating wall that stops oil."

Today there are over 7 billion people on Earth. About half of all the land is used to grow food for everyone. Towns, cities, and roads cover much of the remaining land. This does not leave much room for forests and other natural places where animals live.

---

People are finding smart ways to protect nature while still using its resources. Tree farms are one example. At a tree farm, workers cut down trees in one section while new trees grow in another section. This way, people can get the wood they need without cutting down all the forests.
People are also working to find cleaner ways to make electricity for homes and schools. Today, most electricity comes from oil and coal. Getting these fuels can cause accidents like oil spills. But we can also use wind and sunlight to make electricity. Giant windmills at wind farms create clean, safe electricity. It is possible to protect the environment and still get all the food and energy we need to live healthy lives.

passage_text:
Protecting the Environment
    
    
        After three months of hard work, engineers and scientists from around the world finally stopped the oil spill from the Deepwater Horizon oil rig. They were able to seal the well so no more oil could leak into the ocean water.
During those difficult months, many people worked to protect the waters and beaches around the Gulf of Mexico. One of the first things they did was spread oil booms in the water. An oil boom is like a floating wall that stops oil from spreading. Workers placed these oil booms all along the coast to keep oil away from beaches and wetlands. Once the oil was trapped by the oil booms, special boats came to clean the oil out of the water.

---

Even with all this work, thousands of gallons of oil still washed up on land. Workers spent many months cleaning oil from the beaches. Thanks to lots of hard work, people were able to prevent a complete environmental disaster. We will never know exactly how many fish, shrimp, and other sea animals died from the oil spill, but it could have been much worse. Most importantly, most of the wetlands were saved.
There are many things you can do to help protect the environment. To make things we use every day like bottles, cans, and paper, we need to use a natural resource. A natural resource is something from nature that people use to make products. To make cans, people dig mines and remove metals like aluminum from the earth. Trees are a natural resource used to make paper. Plastic bottles and toys are made from oil, which is also a natural resource.

---

Cans, bottles, and papers can be used again when we recycle them. When you recycle, old items get turned into new ones. This means we need less metal from mines, fewer trees get cut down, and less oil gets used to make new plastic. When we recycle, we help protect the environment!
Today there are over 7 billion people on Earth. About half of all the land is used to grow food for everyone. Towns, cities, and roads cover much of the remaining land. This does not leave much room for forests and other natural places where animals live.

---

People are finding smart ways to protect nature while still using its resources. Tree farms are one example. At a tree farm, workers cut down trees in one section while new trees grow in another section. This way, people can get the wood they need without cutting down all the forests.
People are also working to find cleaner ways to make electricity for homes and schools. Today, most electricity comes from oil and coal. Getting these fuels can cause accidents like oil spills. But we can also use wind and sunlight to make electricity. Giant windmills at wind farms create clean, safe electricity. It is possible to protect the environment and still get all the food and energy we need to live healthy lives.

option_1: cutting down all the trees at once
option_2: using trees to make paper products
option_3: letting new trees grow while others are cut
option_4: covering much of the remaining land
option_1_explanation: Good try! Cutting down all trees at once would hurt nature, not help it. Tree farms do something much smarter to protect forests.
option_2_explanation: Close! Using trees to make things is what happens everywhere, but that doesn't tell us how tree farms protect nature. Think about what makes tree farms special.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The story says workers "cut down trees in one section while new trees grow in another section." This smart system keeps forests safe!
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the story says towns and cities cover land, which is a problem for trees. Tree farms help nature in a different way.

        I am born on a Tuesday at University HospitalColumbus, Ohio,USAa country caughtbetween Black and White.I am born not long from the timeor far from the placewheremy great-great-grandparentsworked the deep rich landunfreedawn till duskunpaiddrank cool water from scooped-out gourdslooked up and followedthe skys mirrored constellationto freedom.

---

I am born as the South explodes,too many people too many yearsenslaved, then emancipatedbut not free, the peoplewho look like mekeep fightingand marchingand getting killedso that todayFebruary 12, 1963and every day from this moment on,brown children like me can grow upfree. Can grow uplearning and voting and walking and ridingwherever we want.I am born in Ohio butthe stories of South Carolina already runlike riversthrough my veins.
question: Why did the author most likely describe the fighting and marching happening when she was born?
option_1: to inform readers about different types of protest methods used throughout history
option_2: to persuade readers that all conflicts should be resolved through peaceful discussion
option_3: to share how the Civil Rights struggle was part of the world she entered as a baby
option_4: to entertain readers with exciting stories about brave people from the past
option_1_explanation: Good try! The author isn't teaching about different ways people protest. She's sharing how "I am born as the South explodes" to show what was happening when she was born.
option_2_explanation: Not quite! The author isn't trying to change how people solve problems. She's telling us about "brown children like me" growing up during the Civil Rights time.
option_3_explanation: Great job! The author says "I am born as the South explodes" to show she came into a world where fighting for Civil Rights was happening. This struggle would help her grow up free.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the author isn't trying to entertain us with exciting stories. She's sharing the serious connection between her birth and people fighting so "brown children like me can grow up free."
differentiation_notes: Targets the author's purpose for describing Civil Rights events in stanza 2 - differs from reference which asks about purpose for entire poem
homogeneity_check: all choices are authorial purposes for including historical details
specificity_check: all explain why the author included fighting/marching information
length_check: A=12 words, B=12 words, C=14 words, D=11 words - balanced within 21%
semantic_distance_check: inform about methods vs persuade about resolution vs share personal context vs entertain are distinct purposes
single_correct_check: only C captures the personal connection between birth moment and historical context
diversity_check: examines author's purpose for Civil Rights descriptions in middle section - different from all other variants

option_2: angry
option_3: hopeful
option_4: tired

option_4_explanation: Close! They might have been tired from the hard journey. But the story says they went "to freedom," so they probably felt hopeful about escaping.

question: What theme does the poem express through the contrast between the speaker's ancestors and the speaker herself?
option_1: Freedom must be earned through individual hard work and determination over time.
option_2: Each generation builds on the struggles of those who came before them.
option_3: Family members should always live in the same geographic region together.
option_4: Historical events are interesting to study but do not affect people today.
option_1_explanation: Good try! The poem doesn't show the speaker working for her own freedom. It shows that other people fought and marched so she could 'grow up free.'
option_2_explanation: You got it! The poem shows how 'brown children like me can grow up free' because others fought before them. Each group of people helped make life better for the next group.
option_3_explanation: Not quite! The speaker lives in Ohio while her family came from South Carolina, and that's okay. The poem is about how past struggles help future kids, not about living in the same place.
option_4_explanation: Nice thinking, but the poem shows history does affect people today! The speaker says the 'stories...run like rivers through my veins' and she's free because of past fights.
